nodes.name: Biology
nodes.description: Biology is the natural science that studies life and living organisms, including their physical structure, chemical processes, molecular interactions, physiological mechanisms, development and evolution.

nodes.name: Physics
nodes.description: Physics is a branch of science that studies matter and its motion and behavior through space and time, along with related concepts such as energy and force.

nodes.name: Chemistry
nodes.description: Chemistry is the scientific discipline involved with elements and compounds composed of atoms, molecules and ions: their composition, structure, properties, behavior and the changes they undergo during a reaction with other substances.

nodes.name: Earth Science
nodes.description: Earth science or geoscience includes all fields of natural science related to planet Earth. This is a branch of science dealing with the physical and chemical constitution of Earth and its atmosphere.

nodes.name: Astronomy
nodes.description: Astronomy is a natural science that studies celestial objects and phenomena. It applies mathematics, physics, and chemistry in an effort to explain the origin of those objects and phenomena and their development.

nodes.name: Ecology
nodes.description: Ecology is the branch of biology which studies the interactions among organisms and their environment. Objects of study include interactions of organisms with each other and with abiotic components of their environment.

nodes.name: Meteorology
nodes.description: Meteorology is a branch of the atmospheric sciences which includes atmospheric chemistry and atmospheric physics, with a major focus on weather forecasting.

nodes.name: Genetics
nodes.description: Genetics is a branch of biology concerned with the study of genes, genetic variation, and heredity in organisms.

nodes.name: Quantum Mechanics
nodes.description: Quantum mechanics, including quantum field theory, is a fundamental theory in physics which describes nature at the smallest scales of energy levels of atoms and subatomic particles.

nodes.name: Biochemistry
nodes.description: Biochemistry or biological chemistry, is the study of chemical processes within and relating to living organisms.

nodes.name: Cell Biology
nodes.description: This is the study of cells, the basic units of life, their structures and functions.

nodes.name: Genetics
nodes.description: This refers to the study of genes, genetic variation, and heredity in living organisms.

nodes.name: Ecology
nodes.description: This is the branch of biology which studies the interactions among organisms and their environment.

nodes.name: Evolutionary Biology
nodes.description: This field studies the origin and descent of species over time, as well as their change.

nodes.name: Molecular Biology
nodes.description: This is a branch of biology that concerns the molecular basis of biological activity, including the interactions between the various systems of a cell.

nodes.name: Physiology
nodes.description: This field studies how organisms, organ systems, individual organs, cells, and biomolecules carry out their physical or chemical functions.

nodes.name: Zoology
nodes.description: This field is devoted to the study of animals, including their structure, embryology, classification, habits, and distribution.

nodes.name: Botany
nodes.description: This is the study of plant life, including their structure, properties, life cycle, interactions with other plants and animals, and responses to different environmental conditions.

nodes.name: Microbiology
nodes.description: This field studies microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, archaea, fungi, and protozoa.

nodes.name: Biotechnology
nodes.description: This is a field of biology involving manipulation of living organisms to produce useful products.

nodes.name: Classical physics
nodes.description: Covers the physics of natural phenomena that can be observed in everyday life. It includes the physics of motion, heat, light, sound, electricity, and magnetism.

nodes.name: Quantum Mechanics
nodes.description: Deals with phenomena at the very smallest level and embraces the behavior of all particles such as atoms and photons.

nodes.name: Relativity
nodes.description: Encompasses the physics of the universe at the highest speeds and energies and encompasses Einstein's theories of special and general relativity.

nodes.name: Thermodynamics
nodes.description: Concerns the study of energy and entropy, including heat, radiation, physical transformations and the behavior of gases.

nodes.name: Astrophysics
nodes.description: A branch of space science that applies the laws of physics to explain the birth, life and death of stars, planets, galaxies, nebulae and other objects in the universe.

nodes.name: Particle Physics
nodes.description: Also known as high energy physics, it is the study of the nature of the particles that constitute matter and radiation.

nodes.name: Nuclear Physics
nodes.description: Primarily concerned with the arrangement and interaction of particles within an atomic nucleus.

nodes.name: Solid State Physics
nodes.description: Studies how atoms arrange themselves into solids and what properties these substances possess as a result.

nodes.name: Organic Chemistry
nodes.description: Organic Chemistry is the branch of chemistry that deals with the structure, properties, composition, reactions, and preparation of carbon-containing compounds.

nodes.name: Inorganic Chemistry
nodes.description: Inorganic Chemistry is the branch of chemistry concerned with the properties and behavior of inorganic compounds.

nodes.name: Physical Chemistry
nodes.description: Physical Chemistry is the branch of chemistry that deals with the study of how matter behaves on a molecular and atomic level, and how chemical reactions occur.

nodes.name: Analytical Chemistry
nodes.description: Analytical Chemistry is the branch of chemistry that examines and measures the chemical composition and structure of materials.

nodes.name: Biochemistry
nodes.description: Biochemistry is the branch of science that explores the chemical processes within and related to living organisms.

nodes.name: Environmental Chemistry
nodes.description: Environmental Chemistry is the scientific study of the chemical and biochemical phenomena that occur in natural places.

nodes.name: Quantum Chemistry
nodes.description: Quantum Chemistry is the branch of chemistry whose primary focus is the application of quantum mechanics in physical models and experiments of chemical systems.

nodes.name: Medicinal Chemistry
nodes.description: Medicinal Chemistry is a multidisciplinary field that uses chemical research techniques to provide potential therapeutics.

nodes.name: Theoretical Chemistry
nodes.description: Theoretical Chemistry is a branch of chemistry that develops theoretical generalizations that are part of the theoretical arsenal of modern chemistry.

nodes.name: Nuclear Chemistry
nodes.description: Nuclear Chemistry is the subfield of chemistry dealing with radioactivity, nuclear processes, and transformations in the nuclei of atoms.

nodes.name: Geology
nodes.description: The study of the solid Earth, including its composition, structure, physical properties, history, and the processes that shape it.

nodes.name: Atmospheric Sciences
nodes.description: The exploration of the Earth's atmosphere, its processes, the effects other systems have on the atmosphere, and the effects of the atmosphere on these other systems.

nodes.name: Oceanography
nodes.description: The study of the physical and biological aspects of the ocean.

nodes.name: Paleontology
nodes.description: The scientific study of the life of past geologic periods, as represented by fossil plants and animals.

nodes.name: Geomorphology
nodes.description: The scientific study of the origin and evolution of topographic and bathymetric features created by physical, chemical or biological processes operating at or near the Earth's surface.

nodes.name: Climatology
nodes.description: The study of the climates, including the long-term weather patterns and trends, and their causes and impacts.

nodes.name: Hydrology
nodes.description: The study of the movement, distribution, and management of water on Earth and other planets, including the water cycle, water resources and environmental watershed sustainability.

nodes.name: Glaciology
nodes.description: The study of glaciers, or more generally ice and natural phenomena that involve ice.

nodes.name: Volcanology
nodes.description: The study of volcanoes, lava, magma, and related geological, geophysical and geochemical phenomena.

nodes.name: Seismology
nodes.description: The scientific study of earthquakes and the propagation of elastic waves through the Earth or through other planet-like bodies.

nodes.name: Stellar Astronomy
nodes.description: The study of stars, including their composition, structure, evolution and death.

nodes.name: Galactic Astronomy
nodes.description: The study of our own Milky Way galaxy and its structure and components, such as its stellar content and distribution, its gas and dust content, and its motion and evolution.

nodes.name: Extragalactic Astronomy
nodes.description: The study of objects (such as galaxies) and phenomena beyond the Milky Way galaxy.

nodes.name: Planetary Science
nodes.description: The scientific study of planets (including Earth), moons, and planetary systems' processes, and their interaction with the solar system.

nodes.name: Astrophysics
nodes.description: The branch of astronomy that deals with the physics of the universe, including the physical properties of celestial bodies, as well as their interactions and behavior.

nodes.name: Cosmology
nodes.description: The scientific study of the largest scale structures and dynamics of the universe and involves fundamental questions about its formation and evolution.

nodes.name: Astrobiology
nodes.description: An interdisciplinary scientific field concerned with the origins, early evolution, distribution, and future of life in the universe.

nodes.name: Population Ecology
nodes.description: Study of the dynamics of species populations and how these populations interact with the environment. It is the branch of ecology that provides a mathematical backbone. Topics can range from population size and growth rates to competition and symbiosis.

nodes.name: Community Ecology
nodes.description: It is the study of the interaction among species within a community. The concept includes species diversity, trophic structure, patterns of organization, temporal changes, influences by external factors such as disturbance, and ecological succession.

nodes.name: Ecosystem Ecology
nodes.description: This branch of ecology primarily focuses on the flow of energy and materials through various biotic and abiotic components of ecosystems. This involves understanding processes such as nutrient cycling, primary production, decomposition, and energy efficiency.

nodes.name: Behavioral Ecology
nodes.description: It is the study of the evolutionary basis and ecological context for animal behavior. Topics include how behavior is shaped by natural selection, how behavior aids survival and reproduction, and the role of behavior in population dynamics.

nodes.name: Conservation Ecology
nodes.description: Conservation ecology is the branch of ecology and evolutionary biology that deals with the preservation, protection, or restoration of the natural environment, natural ecosystems, vegetation, and wildlife.

nodes.name: Landscape Ecology
nodes.description: Landscape ecology is the study of the causes and ecological consequences of spatial pattern in landscapes. It involves understanding pattern-process relationships, landscape change, and the role of scale.

nodes.name: Evolutionary Ecology
nodes.description: This branch of ecology involves the study of how evolutionary processes shape the natural world. Aspects often studied include adaptation, speciation, coevolution, and the role of selection in shaping species.

nodes.name: Climate
nodes.description: The study of long-term atmospheric conditions and trends over large geographic scales, encompassing components like temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressure, wind, and precipitation.

nodes.name: Weather
nodes.description: The study of short-term atmospheric conditions, mainly concerned with prediction and understanding of daily weather patterns and severe weather events.

nodes.name: Atmospheric Physics
nodes.description: The branch of Meteorology that studies the physical properties and processes of the atmosphere including the energy transfer, light scattering, sound propagation, and the dynamics of atmospheric gases.

nodes.name: Atmospheric Chemistry
nodes.description: The study of the chemical composition and reactions in the atmosphere, focusing on air quality, ozone layer depletion, and greenhouse gas emissions.

nodes.name: Hydrometeorology
nodes.description: The science of the water cycle within the atmosphere, including the study of topics like precipitation, evaporation, and transpiration.

nodes.name: Biometeorology
nodes.description: The study of the interaction between atmospheric conditions and living organisms, focusing on how weather and climate affect plants, animals, and human health.

nodes.name: Aerology
nodes.description: The study of the upper layers of the atmosphere, where direct weather observations are not possible.

nodes.name: Micrometeorology
nodes.description: The study of atmospheric phenomena on a small scale, particularly those phenomena that occur near the earth's surface.

nodes.name: Paleoclimatology
nodes.description: The study of the past climates, aiming to understand the climate system and changes.

nodes.name: Numerical Weather Prediction
nodes.description: The use of mathematical models in the prediction of weather patterns and events.

nodes.name: Molecular Genetics
nodes.description: This branch of genetics focuses on the structure and function of genes at a molecular level. Key concepts within molecular genetics include DNA replication, repair, and mutation.

nodes.name: Population Genetics
nodes.description: Population genetics studies the frequencies and interactions of alleles within a population.  It is the foundational discipline of evolutionary biology and includes the study of genetic variation, genetic drift, and natural selection.

nodes.name: Quantitative Genetics
nodes.description: Quantitative genetics focuses on the genetic basis of complex (often multifactorial) traits and their evolution.

nodes.name: Cytogenetics
nodes.description: Cytogenetics involves the study of chromosomes and chromosomal abnormalities, often utilizing techniques such as karyotyping and fluorescent in situ hybridization.

nodes.name: Genomics
nodes.description: Genomics studies the structure, function, evolution, and mapping of genomes (an organism’s complete set of DNA).

nodes.name: Genetic Engineering
nodes.description: This applied branch of genetics involves the direct manipulation of an organism's genes using biotechnology.

nodes.name: Wave-Particle Duality
nodes.description: Describes the phenomena exhibited by particles, such as electrons and photons, where they exhibit properties of both particles and waves.

nodes.name: Superposition
nodes.description: A fundamental principle of quantum mechanics that holds that a physical system—such as an electron—exists partly in all its theoretically possible states simultaneously before being measured or observed.

nodes.name: Quantum Entanglement
nodes.description: A phenomenon in which the quantum states of two or more particles become linked and the state of one particle is directly correlated with the state of the other, regardless of the distance between them.

nodes.name: Quantum Field Theory
nodes.description: An advanced mathematical framework that combines classical field theory, special relativity, and quantum mechanics, and is used to construct physical models of subatomic particles and quasiparticles.

nodes.name: Quantum Tunneling
nodes.description: A phenomenon where particles can tunnel through potential barriers even though they do not apparently have the energy to do so according to classical mechanics.

nodes.name: Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle
nodes.description: A fundamental concept of quantum mechanics that the position and velocity of an object cannot both be precisely measured at the same time.

nodes.name: Schrodinger's Equation
nodes.description: A mathematical equation that describes the changes over time of a physical system in which quantum effects are significant.

nodes.name: Molecular Genetics
nodes.description: It is a sub-discipline of biochemistry that involves the study of the chemical nature and behavioural characteristics of genes in a cell. It majorly focuses on how the genes are transferred from generation to another, how they are expressed, and how they are regulated.

nodes.name: Enzymology
nodes.description: This branch of biochemistry deals with the study of enzymes, their kinetics, structure, function and role in disease. It helps in understanding how enzymes drive metabolic pathways and regulate biochemical reactions in cells.

nodes.name: Metabolism
nodes.description: It is the subset of biochemistry that explores the chemical reactions that occur in organisms. It studies metabolic pathways which are sequences of chemical reactions, where the product of one enzyme serves as the substrate for the next.

nodes.name: Structural Biochemistry
nodes.description: This field of biochemistry is concerned with the molecular structure of biological macromolecules, which includes proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, and lipids. It sits at the interface of biochemistry, physics, and computer science.

nodes.name: Immunology
nodes.description: Although considered a field in its own right, immunology is heavily intertwined with biochemistry. It studies the components of the immune system (like cells, antibodies), their chemical function and interaction in the body. Biochemical techniques are essential in studying and understanding the immune responses.

nodes.name: Nutritional Biochemistry
nodes.description: It pertains to the study of nutrients at the molecular level - their uptake, assimilation, role and metabolic processing within the body. It helps in understanding the role of nutrients in health and disease.

nodes.name: Cell Structure
nodes.description: This aspect of cell biology focuses on the physical structure of cells, including understanding the function of specific cell parts such as the nucleus, the cytoplasm, and the mitochondria.

nodes.name: Cellular Metabolism
nodes.description: This involves studying the chemical reactions that occur within cells, which are responsible for the cell's ability to function, grow, and reproduce.

nodes.name: Cell Growth and Division
nodes.description: This involves understanding the processes of cell growth and division, including mitosis, cytokinesis, and meiosis which are essential for growth and reproduction of organisms.

nodes.name: Cell Signaling
nodes.description: This branch studies how cells communicate with each other via signaling molecules to respond to changes in their environment and work together in an organized way.

nodes.name: Molecular Biology of the Cell
nodes.description: This aspect is focused on the interactions between various systems of a cell, including the interactions between DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis and how these interactions influence cell function.

nodes.name: Cellular Pathology
nodes.description: This is the study of disease at a cellular level, understanding the changes in cellular structure and function that can lead to disease.

nodes.name: Cellular Respiration
nodes.description: This is the study of the series of metabolic processes by which living cells produce energy through the oxidation of organic substances.

nodes.name: Cellular Immunology
nodes.description: This focuses on the components and functions of the immune system at a cellular level, exploring how cells defend the body from infections and disease.

nodes.name: Stem Cell Biology
nodes.description: This examines the unique properties of stem cells, including their potential for regeneration and their use in research and treatment of diseases.

nodes.name: Developmental Cell Biology
nodes.description: This is dedicated to understanding how cells contribute to organismal development, exploring how an organism develops from a single cell to a mature organism.

nodes.name: Mendelian Genetics
nodes.description: This is the study of how traits are passed from parents to offspring based upon the principles proposed by Gregor Mendel in the 19th century. It includes concepts such as dominant and recessive traits, alleles, and genetic inheritance.

nodes.name: Molecular Genetics
nodes.description: This field focuses on the study of the structure and function of genes at a molecular level. It includes the study of DNA, RNA, protein synthesis, and gene regulation.

nodes.name: Population Genetics
nodes.description: This field of genetics studies the genetic composition of populations and how it changes over time. It combines principles from evolutionary theory and Mendelian genetics.

nodes.name: Genomic Genetics
nodes.description: This field studies the entire genome of organisms. The focus is on understanding the structure, function, and evolution of genomes.

nodes.name: Developmental Genetics
nodes.description: This field studies how genes control the growth and development of an organism throughout its lifecycle. This isn't only about physical development but also the development of specific behaviors.

nodes.name: Quantitative Genetics
nodes.description: This field involves the study of complex traits that are influenced by multiple genes and the environment. It involves statistical methods to predict the inheritance of these traits.

nodes.name: Epigenetics
nodes.description: This branch of genetics studies how gene expression can be changed without altering the DNA sequence itself. It involves processes like DNA methylation and histone modification.

nodes.name: Ecosystem Ecology
nodes.description: This subdiscipline of ecology focuses on the flow of energy and matter through local systems, including the interactions of organisms with each other and their physical environment.

nodes.name: Population Ecology
nodes.description: This branch of ecology studies the dynamics of species populations and how these populations interact with the environment. It includes concepts such as population size, density, dispersion, and growth rate.

nodes.name: Community Ecology
nodes.description: Also known as synecology, it looks at how communities or groups of species interact and form functional entities in nature.

nodes.name: Behavioral Ecology
nodes.description: This field of study looks at the ecological and evolutionary basis for animal behavior, and how behavior enables an animal to adapt to its environment.

nodes.name: Conservation Ecology
nodes.description: This focuses on the application of ecological science to conserve and manage biodiversity.

nodes.name: Landscape Ecology
nodes.description: This branch looks at the patterns and processes of a landscape, with a specific emphasis on the interactions between human-induced and natural factors.

nodes.name: Molecular Ecology
nodes.description: This applies molecular biology to ecological questions. It looks at genetic diversity within species and how that influences interactions between organisms.

nodes.name: Evolutionary Ecology
nodes.description: This branch integrates evolutionary and ecological theories to understand the ecological cause of evolution.

nodes.name: Physiological Ecology
nodes.description: This subfield concentrates on how physiological properties, such as metabolism and nutrient needs, influence the distribution and behavior of organisms.

nodes.name: Paleoecology
nodes.description: This refers to the study of the interactions between organisms and/or interactions with their environments across geologic timescales.

nodes.name: Adaptation
nodes.description: The process by which organisms become better suited to their environment through changes in genetic traits. Such changes in traits may occur over generations and can lead to the development of new species.

nodes.name: Natural Selection
nodes.description: A core mechanism of evolution, postulated by Charles Darwin, whereby species with traits that favor survival and reproduction are more likely to pass on their genes to the next generation. Over time, this process leads to a genetic predominance of advantageous traits within a species.

nodes.name: Speciation
nodes.description: The process by which new species arise from existing species. This can occur through different mechanisms like geographic isolation, genetic divergence, and reproductive barriers.

nodes.name: Genetic Drift
nodes.description: An evolutionary mechanism wherein changes in allele frequencies within a population occur due to random chance events, rather than natural selection. It is particularly powerful in small populations, where it can lead to genetic fixation or loss.

nodes.name: Co-evolution
nodes.description: The process where two or more species reciprocally affect each other's evolution. An example is predator-prey interactions, in which the predator's success in hunting and the prey's success in evasion both influence the respective species' evolution.

nodes.name: Evolutionary Developmental Biology
nodes.description: A field of biology that compares the developmental processes of different organisms to infer ancestral relationships between them and discover how developmental processes evolved.

nodes.name: Molecular Evolution
nodes.description: A process of change in the sequence composition of cellular molecules such as DNA, RNA, and proteins across generations. It refers to the evolution at the scale of molecular genetics.

nodes.name: Phylogenetics
nodes.description: The study of the evolutionary relationships among groups of organisms, which is discovered through molecular sequencing data and morphological data matrices.

nodes.name: Microevolution
nodes.description: Evolution on a small scale within single population. It focuses on changes in gene frequency within a population, which can be driven by factors such as mutation, migration, genetic drift, and natural selection.

nodes.name: Macroevolution
nodes.description: Evolution on a grand scale that transcends the boundaries of a single species. This concept focuses on change that occurs at or above the level of species, over geological era, looking at large-scale evolutionary developments and extinctions.

nodes.name: DNA Replication
nodes.description: A process by which a double-stranded DNA molecule is copied to produce two identical DNA molecules.

nodes.name: Protein Synthesis
nodes.description: The process in which cells make proteins, involving transcription and translation of genes into polypeptides.

nodes.name: Gene Expression
nodes.description: The process by which the instructions in our DNA are converted into a functional product, such as a protein.

nodes.name: Cellular Respiration
nodes.description: A set of metabolic reactions taking place in cells of organisms to convert biochemical energy from nutrients into ATP, and then release waste products.

nodes.name: Molecular Genetics
nodes.description: The field of biology and genetics that studies the structure and function of genes at a molecular level.

nodes.name: Genetic Engineering
nodes.description: The process of manually adding new DNA to an organism in order to add one or more new traits that are not already found in that organism.

nodes.name: Epigenetics
nodes.description: The study of changes in organisms caused by modification of gene expression rather than alteration of the genetic code itself.

nodes.name: Signal Transduction
nodes.description: The process by which a chemical or physical signal is transmitted through a cell as a series of molecular events, most commonly protein phosphorylation catalyzed by protein kinases, which ultimately results in a cellular response.

nodes.name: DNA Repair
nodes.description: The collection of processes by which a cell identifies and corrects damage to the DNA molecules that encode its genome.

nodes.name: Molecular Evolution
nodes.description: A field of biology that studies genetic sequence variation and the mechanisms of diversity at a molecular level.

nodes.name: Cellular Physiology
nodes.description: Examines the functioning of cells, studying phenomena such as cell division, synthesis of proteins and enzymes, and how cells send and receive signals

nodes.name: Human Physiology
nodes.description: Dedicated to understanding the functions of the human body at various levels, from cells to organs, and the body's response to changes in the environment

nodes.name: Comparative Physiology
nodes.description: Looks at and compares the functional aspects of different species to understand evolutionary adaptations that have historically worked to keep organisms alive

nodes.name: Cardiovascular Physiology
nodes.description: Looks at the functioning of the heart and blood vessels. It studies aspects like cardiac cycle, blood pressure, and how cardiovascular system responds to exercise and stress

nodes.name: Respiratory Physiology
nodes.description: Examines the workings of the lung and airways, looking into gas exchange, ventilation, and how the body responds to changes in oxygen and carbon dioxide concentration in the blood

nodes.name: Neurophysiology
nodes.description: Focuses on the nervous system and aims to understand the functions of its components, which are related to everything from simple reflexes to complex brain functions

nodes.name: Endocrine Physiology
nodes.description: Studies the functions of the endocrine system, specifically the hormones and the glands that produce them

nodes.name: Gastrointestinal Physiology
nodes.description: Concerned with the operation of the stomach and intestines, looking at processes such as digestion and absorption

nodes.name: Renal Physiology
nodes.description: Deals with kidney function and how they control the composition and volume of the body’s fluids by filtering and excreting or reabsorbing water and solutes

nodes.name: Exercise Physiology
nodes.description: Looks at how the body reacts to physical exercise and how it adapts over time to physical activity

nodes.name: Animal Anatomy
nodes.description: The study of animal body structures. It details the form and function of different parts of the animal body, from microscopic cells to complex structures like organs and tissues.

nodes.name: Animal Physiology
nodes.description: The scientific study of the functions and mechanisms in an animal's body. It focuses on how organs and systems within an animal's body function in synchronized, harmonious ways to keep the body functioning optimally.

nodes.name: Entomology
nodes.description: A specialized subset of zoology that focuses exclusively on the study of insects, their behaviors, systems, and their impact on the ecosystem and human population.

nodes.name: Herpetology
nodes.description: A branch of zoology concerning the study of amphibians (including frogs, toads, salamanders, and newts) and reptiles (including snakes, lizards, amphisbaenids, turtles, terrapins, tortoises, crocodilians, and the tuataras).

nodes.name: Ichthyology
nodes.description: The study of fish. This field encompasses both freshwater and marine species of fish. Researchers might study their biology, classification, distribution, or their importance to ecosystems or to humans.

nodes.name: Ornithology
nodes.description: The scientific study of birds. An ornithologist studies bird species to learn about their behaviors, physiology, and conservation needs.

nodes.name: Mammalogy
nodes.description: A branch of zoology that studies mammals—a class of vertebrates with characteristics such as homeothermic metabolism, fur, four-chambered hearts, and complex nervous systems. Mammalogy has also been known as 'mastology,' 'theriology,' and 'therology.'

nodes.name: Ethology
nodes.description: The scientific study of animal behavior, usually with a focus on behavior under natural conditions. Ethology is a sub-topic of zoology, dealing with the evolutionary implications of animal behavior.

nodes.name: Ecology
nodes.description: The study of the interaction of living organisms with each other and with their physical environment. While ecology as a whole is not confined to the study of animals, Zoology often gives a major focus to the role of animals in their ecosystems.

nodes.name: Paleozoology
nodes.description: Also known as zooarchaeology, it is the study of animal remains from ancient times. Through fossils, scientists can learn about the structure, function and habitats of long-extinct species.

nodes.name: Plant Anatomy
nodes.description: This is the study of the internal structure especially the microscopic structure of plants. It includes aspects like cell structure, plant tissue types, and life cycles.

nodes.name: Plant Physiology
nodes.description: This branch of botany deals with the physical, biochemical, and molecular processes that take place within a plant. It covers aspects such as how plants grow, develop, reproduce and respond to their environment.

nodes.name: Ethnobotany
nodes.description: Ethnobotany is the scientific study of the relationships that exist between people and plants. Ethnobotanists explore how plants are used for such things as food, shelter, medicine, clothing, hunting, and religious ceremonies.

nodes.name: Plant Taxonomy
nodes.description: This is the science of naming, defining and classifying plants. It includes the study of plant classification, nomenclature, and identification.

nodes.name: Plant Pathology
nodes.description: Also known as Phytopathology, this is the scientific study of plant diseases caused by pathogens and environmental conditions. It involves the study of the nature, causes, prevention, and treatment of plant diseases.

nodes.name: Plant Ecology
nodes.description: This is the study of how plants interact with their environment, including other plants, animals, and the physical environment. Topics covered may include plant distribution, population dynamics, and species diversity.

nodes.name: Plant Evolution
nodes.description: This branch of botany is concerned with the process of change in all its myriad forms of plants over the course of time, especially the changes in plant populations and species over generations.

nodes.name: Plant Genetics
nodes.description: This is the study of how traits are inherited in plants, the genetic variation in plant populations, and how genetic information is transferred from parents to offspring. It helps in understanding and manipulating plant breeding for desired traits.

nodes.name: Paleobotany
nodes.description: This is the study of fossil plants and the evolution of plants through geological time. Paleobotanists use plant fossils as records of past climates, environments, and evolution.

nodes.name: Bacteriology
nodes.description: The study of bacteria, including their classification, biochemistry, and role in disease.

nodes.name: Virology
nodes.description: The study of viruses, including their classification, evolution, genetic and molecular properties, and how they use host cells for replication.

nodes.name: Mycology
nodes.description: The study of fungi, including their genetic and biochemical properties, classification, and use in medicine and food.

nodes.name: Parasitology
nodes.description: The study of parasites, the parasitic diseases they cause, their life cycles, and their interactions with host organisms.

nodes.name: Immunology
nodes.description: The study of immunity, including how the immune system responds to infections and diseases, and how it can be manipulated to diagnose and treat various conditions.

nodes.name: Phycology
nodes.description: The study of algae, including their classification, physiology, and use in the environment and the food industry.

nodes.name: Microbial Genetics
nodes.description: The study of how genes are organized and regulated in microbes in relation to their cellular functions.

nodes.name: Microbial Physiology
nodes.description: The study of how microbial cells function biochemically, including how they metabolize nutrients and how they reproduce.

nodes.name: Environmental Microbiology
nodes.description: The study of the role and functions of microorganisms in earth's ecosystem to learn their contribution in climate change, degradation of pollutants etc.

nodes.name: Industrial Microbiology
nodes.description: The exploitation of microbes for use in industrial processes, such as industrial fermentation and wastewater treatment.

nodes.name: Genetic Engineering
nodes.description: This involves the direct manipulation of an organism's genes using biotechnology. It is a set of technologies used to change the genetic makeup of cells, including the transfer of genes within and across species boundaries to produce improved or novel organisms.

nodes.name: Cell and Tissue Culture Technologies
nodes.description: These are procedures for maintaining or growing cell lines or tissues under sterile conditions in a culture medium. It's often used in cloning and in the production of genetically modified organisms.

nodes.name: Bioprocessing Technology
nodes.description: This involves the use of living cells or their components (e.g., bacteria, enzymes, chloroplasts) to manufacture desired products. This could range from alcohol production through fermentation, to producing hormones with genetically-modified bacteria.

nodes.name: Bioinformatics
nodes.description: This is an interdisciplinary field that develops methods and software tools for understanding biological data, particularly when the data sets are large and complex.

nodes.name: Stem Cell Techniques
nodes.description: Methods related to the extraction, cultivation and application of stem cells, which can be used to replicate and replace damaged tissues/organs.

nodes.name: Pharmacogenomics
nodes.description: This is the study of how genes affect a person's response to drugs. This relatively new field combines pharmacology (the science of drugs) and genomics (the study of genes and their functions) to develop effective, safe medications and doses that will be tailored to a person's genetic makeup.

nodes.name: Nanobiotechnology
nodes.description: Defined as the intersection of nanotechnology and biotechnology, it deals with various methodical approaches including green nanotechnology, materials science, and tissue engineering.

nodes.name: Epigenetics
nodes.description: Epigenetics represents the study of changes in organisms caused by modification of gene expression rather than alteration of the genetic code itself, often as a response to a particular environment or life experience.

nodes.name: Proteomics
nodes.description: Proteomics is the large-scale study of proteins, particularly their structures and functions. It aims at understanding the structure of the cellular protein network and the function of the network to predict cell behavior.

nodes.name: Environmental Biotechnology
nodes.description: It refers to the use of biotechnological methods for the sustainable processing and control of waste materials, environmental decontamination and production of bioenergy.

nodes.name: Kinematics
nodes.description: Kinematics is the study of motion of objects without reference to the forces which cause the motion.

nodes.name: Dynamics
nodes.description: Dynamics deals with the effect that forces have on the motion of objects, including concepts like force, mass and acceleration.

nodes.name: Statics
nodes.description: Statics is the branch of physics that deals with physical systems in a state of equilibrium, where all forces are balanced.

nodes.name: Optics
nodes.description: Optics studies the behavior of light, its interactions with matter, and the instruments used to gather data about it.

nodes.name: Thermodynamics
nodes.description: Thermodynamics deals with heat, temperature and their relation to energy, radiation, and physical properties of matter.

nodes.name: Fluid Mechanics
nodes.description: Fluid mechanics studies the motion of fluids (liquids, gases, and plasmas) and the forces on them.

nodes.name: Wave Mechanics
nodes.description: Wave mechanics is a branch of physics that describes the behavior of waves, such as sound waves, light waves, and waves on strings.

nodes.name: Electromagnetism
nodes.description: Electromagnetism refers to the study of the electromagnetic force, one of the fundamental forces that occur between particles containing an electrical charge.

nodes.name: Wave-Particle Duality
nodes.description: The idea that every elementary particle exhibits properties of both particles and waves.

nodes.name: Quantum Superposition
nodes.description: The principle that particles can exist in multiple states simultaneously, only collapsing to one state when observed.

nodes.name: Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle
nodes.description: The concept that it's impossible to accurately know both the position and momentum of a particle at the same time.

nodes.name: Quantum Entanglement
nodes.description: A phenomenon where particles become interconnected and the state of one directly affects the state of the other, despite the distance between them.

nodes.name: Schrodinger's Equation
nodes.description: A mathematical equation that describes how the quantum state of a quantum system changes with time.

nodes.name: Quantum Field Theory
nodes.description: A theoretical framework for constructing quantum mechanical models of subatomic particles in particle physics and quantum chemistry.

nodes.name: Quantum Tunneling
nodes.description: A quantum mechanic phenomenon where a particle passes through a potential barrier despite not having enough energy to do so classically.

nodes.name: Special Relativity
nodes.description: This aspect of relativity involves phenomena that take place in the absence of gravity and where physical laws are invariant under transformations between inertial systems. It encompasses theories such as time dilation, length contraction, and E=mc^2.

nodes.name: General Relativity
nodes.description: This is a theory of gravitation developed by Einstein, extending special relativity to incorporate gravity. The theory explains gravity as a 'curvature' of space-time caused by mass and energy.

nodes.name: Lorentz Transformations
nodes.description: These are mathematical formulas that relate the space and time coordinates of two observers moving at a constant velocity relative to each other. They are a fundamental part of the theory of special relativity.

nodes.name: Space-time
nodes.description: A concept in relativity where the three physical dimensions of space and the one dimension of time are fused into a four-dimensional continuum.

nodes.name: Gravitational Waves
nodes.description: Predicted by Einstein’s theory of general relativity, these are disturbances in the curvature of space-time caused by accelerated masses. They travel as waves outward from their source at the speed of light.

nodes.name: Black Holes
nodes.description: A region of space-time exhibiting such strong gravitational effects that nothing—not even particles and electromagnetic radiation such as light—can escape from inside it. The theory of general relativity predicts that a sufficiently compact mass can deform space-time to form a black hole.

nodes.name: Einstein Field Equations
nodes.description: These are a set of 10 interrelated differential equations that describe the fundamental interaction of gravitation as a result of spacetime being curved by matter and energy. They are a crucial part of the theory of general relativity.

nodes.name: Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics
nodes.description: This law introduces the concept of thermal equilibrium and provides a postulate for the definition of temperature. It states that if two systems are in thermal equilibrium with a third system, then they are in thermal equilibrium with each other.

nodes.name: First Law of Thermodynamics
nodes.description: Often considered the Principle of Energy Conservation, it states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred or transformed from one form to another.

nodes.name: Second Law of Thermodynamics
nodes.description: This law addresses the concept of entropy and the directionality of thermodynamic processes, stating that in a closed system, entropy can only stay the same or increase over time.

nodes.name: Third Law of Thermodynamics
nodes.description: The Third Law states that as a system approaches absolute zero (0 Kelvin), the entropy of the system approaches a minimum value. This is often interpreted as 'all processes cease at absolute zero'.

nodes.name: Thermodynamic Equilibrium
nodes.description: A state in which a system is in thermal, mechanical, and chemical equilibrium, implying that all changes within a system are cyclical and reversible.

nodes.name: Thermodynamic Cycles
nodes.description: These are sequences of changes in a system which, after running through the series of stages, return the system to its initial state. Examples include the Carnot cycle, the Otto cycle, etc.

nodes.name: Thermodynamic Potentials
nodes.description: These are quantities that are used to determine the equilibrium state of a system under certain conditions, such as internal energy, enthalpy, Helmholtz free energy, and Gibbs free energy.

nodes.name: Statistical Thermodynamics
nodes.description: An approach to thermodynamics based on statistics and probability, which provides a deeper understanding of entropy and the behavior of large ensembles of particles.

nodes.name: Stellar Astrophysics
nodes.description: This branch of astrophysics focuses on the structure and evolution of stars, physical processes occuring in stars, and their characteristics.

nodes.name: Galactic Astrophysics
nodes.description: This field involves the study of the Milky Way and its structure, as well as the entities within it such as the interstellar medium and stars.

nodes.name: Extragalactic Astrophysics
nodes.description: This subfield focuses on objects outside of our galaxy, including other galaxies, quasars, and large-scale cosmic structures.

nodes.name: Cosmology
nodes.description: This branch is concerned with the nature of the universe as a whole, looking into its origin, evolution, and eventual fate.

nodes.name: Astroparticle Physics
nodes.description: This field combines aspects of particle physics and astrophysics, studying particles of astronomical origin and their relation to cosmology and astrophysics.

nodes.name: Astrobiology
nodes.description: This multidisciplinary field studies the potential of life in the universe, including the search for extraterrestrial life and the effects of outer space on living organisms.

nodes.name: Planetary Science
nodes.description: This branch of astrophysics deals with the study of planets, moons, and planetary systems and the processes that form them.

nodes.name: Observational Astrophysics
nodes.description: This field is dedicated to the observation and data collection for various celestial bodies and phenomena.

nodes.name: Theoretical Astrophysics
nodes.description: This branch is dedicated to improving our understanding of physical laws in the universe by formulating theoretical models, conducting simulations, and making predictions.

nodes.name: Atomic Structure
nodes.description: A subset of particle physics focusing on the understanding of protons, neutrons, and electrons and how they form atomic structures.

nodes.name: Quantum Field Theory
nodes.description: A key theoretical framework in particle physics that combines classical field theory, special relativity, and quantum mechanics. It describes how particles interact and undergo transformation.

nodes.name: Elementary Particles
nodes.description: This involves the study of the smallest individual units of matter and energy, such as quarks, leptons and gauge bosons. This is fundamental to understanding the behaviours and interactions in particle physics.

nodes.name: Particle Decay
nodes.description: The process where a parent particle transforms into a set of other particles. This includes study of weak nuclear force and principles such as conservation of energy and momentum.

nodes.name: Particle Interactions and Forces
nodes.description: These are studies around the four fundamental forces known in nature: gravitational, electromagnetic, strong nuclear, and weak nuclear. Each of these forces contribute to the interactions and transformations of particles.

nodes.name: High Energy Physics
nodes.description: This field is concerned with the study of particles and their interactions in high-energy states. Colliders and detectors are used to create and observe these conditions.

nodes.name: The Standard Model
nodes.description: The theoretical framework that describes the electromagnetic, weak, and strong nuclear interactions. It is a key building block of our understanding of the universe at the smallest scales.

nodes.name: Neutrino Physics
nodes.description: Neutrinos are subatomic particles with no charge and very small mass. Neutrino physics explores the properties and behaviours of these particles, including their role in cosmic events.

nodes.name: Dark Matter and Dark Energy
nodes.description: These are forms of matter and energy that cannot yet be detected directly, but whose existence is inferred from their gravitational effects on visible matter. This is a cutting edge area of particle physics research.

nodes.name: Radiation
nodes.description: A subconcept of nuclear physics that includes the study of alpha, beta, and gamma decay, and the emissions associated with each.

nodes.name: Nuclear Fission
nodes.description: A part of nuclear physics that deals with the division of a heavy nucleus into two lighter ones, with a release of a large amount of energy.

nodes.name: Nuclear Fusion
nodes.description: A subconcept of nuclear physics which involves the combination of two light nuclei to form a heavier one, resulting in the release of energy.

nodes.name: Radioactive Decay
nodes.description: A key aspect of nuclear physics that involves the study of unstable isotopes breaking down and releasing radiation.

nodes.name: Nuclear Reactions
nodes.description: Part of nuclear physics that studies the processes in which two atomic nuclei collide to produce one or more different nuclides.

nodes.name: Nuclear Force
nodes.description: A subconcept of nuclear physics which involves the study of the strong interaction which binds protons and neutrons in an atomic nucleus.

nodes.name: Nuclear Structure
nodes.description: Part of nuclear physics which studies the arrangement of protons and neutrons in the atomic nucleus and how they interact.

nodes.name: Particle Physics
nodes.description: Although it's a large field on its own, it is also a subset of nuclear physics since it covers the study of the subatomic particles contained within the atomic nucleus.

nodes.name: Crystal Structure
nodes.description: Describes the arrangement of atoms in a crystalline material. It also encompasses the principles of symmetry in crystals.

nodes.name: Quantum Mechanics
nodes.description: Provides a mathematical description of the wave–particle duality, which is a fundamental concept in Solid State Physics. It's the theoretical base when studying electrons behavior in solids.

nodes.name: Band Theory
nodes.description: Explains the behavior of electrons in solids by considering their allowed energy levels. This theory is central for understanding electronic properties of materials.

nodes.name: Superconductivity
nodes.description: Explores the phenomena whereby a material can conduct electricity without resistance. This subject is heavily based on quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics.

nodes.name: Semiconductors
nodes.description: Materials with electrical conductivity due to activated or added impurity ions. Their study is crucial in modern electronic and photonic devices.

nodes.name: Magnetism
nodes.description: Deals with the principles of magnetic materials and phenomena.

nodes.name: Lattice Dynamics
nodes.description: Study of the vibrations of atoms about their equilibrium positions in a crystal lattice. As such, it is directly related to properties such as thermal conductivity of materials.

nodes.name: Ferroelectricity
nodes.description: This is the examination of materials that possess a spontaneous electric polarization that can be reversed by the application of an external electric field.

nodes.name: Optical Properties of Solids
nodes.description: Analyzes how solids interact with light, leading to applications such as lasers and LEDs.

nodes.name: Hard/Soft Condensed Matter
nodes.description: The distinction between hard and soft condensed matter is more about the tools used to study them, with hard matter typically studied by methods of quantum mechanics and soft matter by statistical mechanics.

nodes.name: Alkanes
nodes.description: These are the simplest form of organic compounds. They consist only of carbon and hydrogen atoms, with single bonds between the carbon atoms.

nodes.name: Alkenes
nodes.description: Also known as olefins, these hydrocarbons have one or more double bonds between carbon atoms.

nodes.name: Alkynes
nodes.description: These are hydrocarbons that contain one or more carbon–carbon triple bonds.

nodes.name: Cycloalkanes
nodes.description: These are types of alkanes that have one or more rings of carbon atoms.

nodes.name: Aromatic hydrocarbons
nodes.description: Also made of carbon and hydrogen, these organic compounds consist of planar and cyclic molecules with delocalized electrons.

nodes.name: Alcohols
nodes.description: These are organic compounds in which a hydroxyl group (-OH) is bonded to a carbon atom.

nodes.name: Aldehydes and Ketones
nodes.description: These are types of organic compounds where a carbon atom shares a double bond with an oxygen atom, a single bond with a hydrogen atom (in aldehydes), and a single bond with another carbon atom (in ketones).

nodes.name: Carboxylic acids
nodes.description: These are organic compounds that contain a carboxyl (-COOH) functional group.

nodes.name: Amines
nodes.description: These are organic compounds and functional groups that contain a basic nitrogen atom with a lone pair of electrons.

nodes.name: Esters
nodes.description: These are organic compounds made by replacing the hydrogen of an acid by an alkyl or other organic group.

nodes.name: Periodic Table
nodes.description: The periodic table is a tool that organizes elements based on their chemical properties and atomic structure. It is fundamental to the study of inorganic chemistry.

nodes.name: Coordination Chemistry
nodes.description: Coordination chemistry involves the study of coordination compounds, or specifically, the chemical compounds that  involve coordinate covalent bonds.

nodes.name: Acid-Base Chemistry
nodes.description: Acid-base chemistry is a key part of inorganic chemistry, studying how certain kinds of substances (acids and bases) can balance each other.

nodes.name: Organometallic Chemistry
nodes.description: Organometallic chemistry is the study of chemical compounds containing bonds between a carbon atom of an organic molecule and a metal, including alkaline, alkaline earth, transition metal, and other cases.

nodes.name: Bioinorganic Chemistry
nodes.description: The part of inorganic chemistry that deals with the role of metals in biology, i.e., the study of the interaction between metal ions and living tissue, especially the transport and storage of metal ions in proteins.

nodes.name: Solid State Chemistry
nodes.description: Solid state chemistry is the study of the synthesis, structure, and properties of solid phase materials, particularly, but not necessarily exclusively of, non-molecular solids.

nodes.name: Environmental Inorganic Chemistry
nodes.description: Environmental inorganic chemistry includes the study of both the behavior and effects of natural inorganic substances in the environment and the synthesis of inorganic compounds for remediation or removal of pollutants.

nodes.name: Thermodynamics
nodes.description: Thermodynamics is the branch of physical chemistry that deals with the relationships between heat, work, temperature, and energy. It studies how these quantities are interrelated and how changes in one can affect the others.

nodes.name: Quantum Chemistry
nodes.description: Quantum chemistry, also called quantum mechanics, is a sub-discipline of physical chemistry that uses principles of quantum theory to understand and explain the nature of molecules, atoms and subatomic particles. It involves the calculation of properties such as geometry, vibrational frequencies, electronic excitation energies, ionization energies, and others.

nodes.name: Kinetics
nodes.description: Kinetics, also known as chemical kinetics, is the part of physical chemistry that deals with the rates of chemical reactions, how reaction rates change under different conditions, and what molecular events occur during the reaction.

nodes.name: Spectroscopy
nodes.description: Spectroscopy is a sub-field of physical chemistry that involves the use of light (including infrared, ultraviolet, and visible light) to examine the structures and properties of matter. It is a powerful analytical tool used to identify and quantify the presence of different elements or substances within a sample.

nodes.name: Statistical Mechanics
nodes.description: Statistical mechanics is an area of physical chemistry that uses statistics to simplify the complex interactions in a system. It provides a link between the microscopic properties of individual atoms and molecules and the macroscopic, bulk properties of materials, thus explaining thermodynamics as a result of the classical and quantum mechanical behaviors of systems.

nodes.name: Surface Chemistry
nodes.description: Surface chemistry deals with the study of chemical reactions at interfaces. It is closely associated with phase-boundary and colloid science.

nodes.name: Electrochemistry
nodes.description: Electrochemistry is a branch of physical chemistry that studies chemical reactions which take place in a solution at the interface of an electron conductor and an ionic conductor, and which involve electron transfer between the electrode and the electrolyte or species in solution.

nodes.name: Quantitative Analysis
nodes.description: This field of analytical chemistry is concerned with the measurement and quantification of samples. Techniques like gravimetric analysis, volumetric analysis, or spectroscopic analysis are used for quantifying unknown substances.

nodes.name: Qualitative Analysis
nodes.description: This is the part of analytical chemistry that is about the identification of chemical compounds in a sample. Techniques used for qualitative analysis include infrared spectroscopy, nuclear magnetic resonance, or mass spectrometry.

nodes.name: Instrumental Analysis
nodes.description: Instrumental analysis involves the use of machines to measure physical quantities of samples such as light absorption, fluorescence, or electrical conductivity, which are then translated into chemical information such as concentration or identity of a sample.

nodes.name: Chromatography
nodes.description: Chromatography is a physical method of separation that distributes components to separate between two phases, one stationary (stationary phase), the other (the mobile phase) flowing in a specific direction. It is widely used in analytical chemistry for the separation, identification, and quantification of components in a mixture.

nodes.name: Electroanalytical Methods
nodes.description: Electroanalytical methods measure the potential (volts) and/or current (amps) in an electrochemical cell containing the analyte. These methods can be classified into several categories including potentiometry (the measurement of the potential of an electrochemical cell), coulometry (the measurement of the electric charge), and voltammetry (electrical current measurement of an electrochemical cell while actively altering the cell's potential).

nodes.name: Spectroscopy
nodes.description: Spectroscopy in analytical chemistry is the study of the interaction between matter and electromagnetic radiation. Techniques such as infrared spectroscopy, nuclear magnetic resonance, or UV/Vis spectroscopy are widely used for the analysis of chemical substances.

nodes.name: Chemometric Analysis
nodes.description: Chemometrics is the science of extracting information from chemical systems by data-driven means. Chemometric techniques apply mathematical and statistical methods to provide maximum chemical information by analyzing chemical data.

nodes.name: Enzymology
nodes.description: Enzymology is a subconcept of biochemistry that studies enzymes, their kinetics, structure, function and role in complex biological processes.

nodes.name: Metabolism
nodes.description: Metabolism refers to the set of life-sustaining chemical reactions in organisms. It's a subfield of biochemistry that involves catabolism and anabolism.

nodes.name: Molecular Genetics
nodes.description: It is a subfield of biochemistry that explores the structure and function of genes at a molecular level. This field combines both biochemistry and genetics.

nodes.name: Structural Biology
nodes.description: Structural Biology is a branch of biochemistry that focuses on predicting and determining the 3D structure of biological macromolecules.

nodes.name: Proteomics
nodes.description: A part of biochemistry that focuses on studying the structure and function of proteins, particularly their roles in biochemical reactions within a cell.

nodes.name: Biochemical Signalling
nodes.description: This subconcept deals with how biochemical substances give signals and interact to drive fundamental biological processes.

nodes.name: Immunology
nodes.description: Immunology, though a vast field itself, is also a subset of biochemistry. It deals with the functioning of the immune system in states of both health and disease.

nodes.name: Nutritional Biochemistry
nodes.description: This subfield investigates how various nutrients or dietary substances influence the health of cells and organisms.

nodes.name: Chemical Composition of the Atmosphere
nodes.description: This subconcept involves the study of the elements and compounds that make up our atmosphere, including nitrogen, oxygen, argon, carbon dioxide, and trace amounts of other gases.

nodes.name: Biogeochemical Cycles
nodes.description: This deals with the study of how chemicals move through terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, specifically focusing on cyclic pathways. Key cycles studied typically include the water cycle, carbon cycle, nitrogen cycle, and phosphorus cycle.

nodes.name: Chemical Pollutants and Bioaccumulation
nodes.description: This focuses on the study of harmful chemicals that may contaminate the environment, and how they build up in organisms over time.

nodes.name: Chemical Kinetics in Environmental Systems
nodes.description: This is the study of the rates at which environmental chemical reactions occur, how these rates are affected by various factors, and what these reactions yield.

nodes.name: Green Chemistry
nodes.description: This branch emphasizes the design of products and processes that minimize the use and generation of hazardous substances, applying a set of principles focused on reducing environmental damage.

nodes.name: Ocean Chemistry
nodes.description: This addresses the study of the chemical composition and processes of the ocean, including carbon dioxide sinks, changes in acidity, and nutrient distribution.

nodes.name: Soil Chemistry
nodes.description: This involves the study of the chemical properties, composition, reactions and processes of soils, and how these impact on the broader environment.

nodes.name: Aquatic Chemistry
nodes.description: This involves the study of the chemical substances and reactions in freshwater and saltwater environments.

nodes.name: Quantum Mechanics Principles
nodes.description: These are the fundamental principles and theories that underlie all of quantum chemistry.

nodes.name: Wave-particle Duality
nodes.description: The concept that every elementary particle or quantic entity may be partly described in terms not only of particles, but also waves.

nodes.name: Molecular Orbital Theory
nodes.description: A method for determining molecular structure in which electrons are not assigned to individual bonds between atoms, but are treated as moving under the influence of the nuclei in the whole molecule.

nodes.name: Quantum Tunneling
nodes.description: A phenomenon in which particles penetrate a potential energy barrier with a height greater than the total energy of the particles.

nodes.name: Quantum Chemistry Computational Methods
nodes.description: Methods used in quantum chemistry to solve the Schrödinger equation such as Hartree–Fock method and Density functional theory (DFT).

nodes.name: Chemical Bonding and Structure
nodes.description: How quantum chemistry describes the forces between atoms and the resulting molecule structures.

nodes.name: Spectroscopy
nodes.description: The study of the interaction between matter and electromagnetic radiation as a function of the wavelength or frequency of the radiation, a critical tool for probing electronic and molecular structure.

nodes.name: Quantum Dynamics
nodes.description: The study of motions and their causes in quantum systems as guided by the laws of quantum mechanics.

nodes.name: Drug Discovery
nodes.description: An integral part of medicinal chemistry which involves the identification of candidates for developing into new medicine.

nodes.name: Pharmacology
nodes.description: A branch within medicinal chemistry that focuses on the action of drugs and their biochemical effects.

nodes.name: Pharmaceutical Analysis
nodes.description: The study and practice of analyzing drugs to determine their components and identify their molecular structures.

nodes.name: Pharmaceutics
nodes.description: The discipline of pharmacy that deals with all facets of the process of turning a new chemical entity (NCE) or old drugs into a medication.

nodes.name: Biochemistry
nodes.description: The area of chemistry that explores the chemical processes within and related to living organisms.

nodes.name: Molecular Pharmacognosy
nodes.description: The intensive study of the molecules involved in traditional medicine, their activities, their uses and their delivery systems.

nodes.name: Medicinal Organic Chemistry
nodes.description: The study of organic compounds and their role in medicinal chemistry, including drug design and synthesis.

nodes.name: Toxicology
nodes.description: The scientific study of effects of poisons, drugs, or chemicals on living organisms.

nodes.name: Quantum Chemistry
nodes.description: The area of chemistry that involves the application of quantum mechanics to physical models and experiments. It includes the computation and prediction of properties such as structure, dynamics, and reactivity of molecules.

nodes.name: Statistical Mechanics
nodes.description: The branch of theoretical chemistry that uses statistics to explain and predict the macroscopic behavior of systems based on the microscopic properties of their constituents. It deals with the study of thermodynamic quantities such as temperature, pressure, and volume.

nodes.name: Molecular Modelling
nodes.description: A collection of mathematical techniques used to represent and simulate the behavior of molecules and molecular systems. This subconcept includes the use of models to predict molecular structures, dynamics, and interactions.

nodes.name: Computational Chemistry
nodes.description: The use of computer simulation to solve chemical problems. It includes methods used to calculate the structure and properties of molecules, such as molecular dynamics and density functional theory.

nodes.name: Chemical Kinetics
nodes.description: The branch of chemistry that concerns the rates of chemical reactions. It involves studying how different experimental conditions can influence the speed of a chemical reaction.

nodes.name: Quantum Mechanics
nodes.description: The branch of theoretical chemistry that focuses on the study and interpretation of atomic and molecular structures and behaviors. It involves the principles and applications of quantum theory to chemistry.

nodes.name: Spectroscopy
nodes.description: The study of the interaction between matter and electromagnetic radiation. In theoretical chemistry, it is used to study the structures and dynamics of molecules.

nodes.name: Radioativity
nodes.description: This studies the spontaneous emission of particles and/or radiation from unstable nuclei. It includes sub-subconcepts like alpha decay, beta decay, and gamma decay.

nodes.name: Nuclear Reactions
nodes.description: This deals with the interactions between two nuclei, or a nucleus and a subatomic particle. Sub-subconcepts include nuclear fission, nuclear fusion and neutron reactions.

nodes.name: Nuclear Energy
nodes.description: This involves the study of how energy is produced, used and managed in nuclear reactions, such as in a nuclear power plant.

nodes.name: Nuclear Decay
nodes.description: This relates to the process by which an unstable nucleus loses energy by emitting radiation. It includes studying half-life, decay chains, and radioactive dating.

nodes.name: Nuclear Structure
nodes.description: This is the study of the constituents (protons, neutrons) and configurations of atomic nuclei.

nodes.name: Nuclear Medicine
nodes.description: This is an application of nuclear chemistry where radioactive substances are used in diagnosis, treatment, and research.

nodes.name: Nuclear Safety
nodes.description: This involves the study and practice of safety measures in dealing with nuclear technology and nuclear reactions, including containment, waste storage, and regulations.

nodes.name: Mineralogy
nodes.description: The study of minerals, including their classification, identification, properties, formation, distribution, importance, and uses.

nodes.name: Petrology
nodes.description: The branch of geology that studies the origins, composition, distribution and structure of rocks.

nodes.name: Volcanology
nodes.description: The study of volcanoes, lava, magma, and related geological phenomena.

nodes.name: Seismology
nodes.description: The study of earthquakes and the propagation of elastic waves through the Earth.

nodes.name: Paleontology
nodes.description: The branch of geology that studies the history of life on Earth through fossils.

nodes.name: Stratigraphy
nodes.description: Stratigraphy is a branch of geology concerned with the study of rock layers (strata) and layering (stratification).

nodes.name: Geomorphology
nodes.description: The scientific study of the origin and evolution of topographic and bathymetric features created by physical or chemical processes operating at or near Earth's surface.

nodes.name: Geochemistry
nodes.description: The science that uses the tools and principles of chemistry to explain the mechanisms behind major geological systems and cycles.

nodes.name: Geophysics
nodes.description: The study of the physical properties and processes of the Earth and its surrounding space environment.

nodes.name: Hydrogeology
nodes.description: The area of geology that deals with the distribution and movement of groundwater in the soil and rocks of the Earth's crust (commonly in aquifers).

nodes.name: Meteorology
nodes.description: The scientific study of the atmosphere that focuses on weather processes and forecasting.

nodes.name: Climatology
nodes.description: The study of climate, scientifically defined as weather conditions averaged over a period of time. It includes the study of climate change and variability.

nodes.name: Atmospheric chemistry
nodes.description: The branch of atmospheric sciences which studies the chemistry of the Earth's atmosphere and that of other planets.

nodes.name: Atmospheric physics
nodes.description: The application of physics to the study of the atmosphere to understand phenomena such as the water cycle, optical effects, radiation, dynamics, and weather patterns.

nodes.name: Atmospheric dynamics
nodes.description: The study of motion systems of meteorological significance. It combines fluid dynamics and thermodynamics.

nodes.name: Global Climate Modeling
nodes.description: It is an area within climatology that uses mathematical models to simulate the interactions of the important drivers of climate, including atmosphere, oceans, land surface and ice.

nodes.name: Aeronomy
nodes.description: The study of the upper atmosphere, where dissociation and ionization are important.

nodes.name: Chemical Oceanography
nodes.description: This branch focuses on the chemistry of the ocean and its effects on the seawater's properties and behaviors.

nodes.name: Physical Oceanography
nodes.description: The study of physical conditions and physical processes within the ocean, especially the motions and physical properties of ocean water.

nodes.name: Biological Oceanography
nodes.description: Also known as marine biology, it involves the study of the animals, plants, and microbes of the oceans and their ecological interaction with the ocean.

nodes.name: Geological Oceanography
nodes.description: This involves the study of the structure, morphology, evolution and processes of the ocean floor.

nodes.name: Marine Geophysics
nodes.description: A subfield of geophysics, it uses quantitative methods to analyze the marine environment.

nodes.name: Paleoceanography
nodes.description: The study of the history of the oceans in the geologic past with regard to circulation, chemistry, biology, geology and patterns of sedimentation.

nodes.name: Marine Ecology
nodes.description: The study of how organisms interact with each other and the environment in the marine environment.

nodes.name: Ocean Engineering
nodes.description: The design of offshore structures, ships, harbors, and other man-made entities within the ocean.

nodes.name: Marine Chemistry
nodes.description: The study of the chemical composition and chemical processes of the world’s oceans.

nodes.name: Operational Oceanography
nodes.description: The practice of routinely collecting oceanographic data, processing it quickly and disseminating the analyzed data to stakeholders.

nodes.name: Vertebrate Paleontology
nodes.description: This field focuses on the study of ancient, fossilized animals with backbones.

nodes.name: Invertebrate Paleontology
nodes.description: A subfield concerned with the study of ancient animals without backbones.

nodes.name: Paleobotany
nodes.description: A specialization focusing on the study of fossilized plants and plant-like organisms.

nodes.name: Micropaleontology
nodes.description: This branch deals with the study of microscopic fossil remains of hard-shelled organisms.

nodes.name: Paleoecology
nodes.description: This field is about researching the interactions between ancient organisms and their environment.

nodes.name: Paleobiogeography
nodes.description: The study of geographic distribution of ancient organisms gives insights into evolution, ecology, and climatology.

nodes.name: Biostratigraphy
nodes.description: This branch utilises fossils to date and correlate rock layers.

nodes.name: Taphonomy
nodes.description: The study of how organisms decay and become fossilized.

nodes.name: Ichnology
nodes.description: The study of traces left behind by organisms, such as footprints, burrows, or feeding marks.

nodes.name: Paleogenetics
nodes.description: A field involving study of preservation and evolution of ancient DNA.

nodes.name: Fluvial Geomorphology
nodes.description: It is the study of the role of rivers in shaping the landscape. It encompasses understanding the processes associated with rivers, such as erosion and sedimentation, and the forms they create, such as valleys and floodplains.

nodes.name: Glacial Geomorphology
nodes.description: This refers to the study of landforms created by the action of glaciers and ice sheets. It includes the study of glacial erosion processes and the understanding of features like cirques, arêtes, and moraines.

nodes.name: Coastal Geomorphology
nodes.description: This is the study of how the coastline is formed and changes over time. Its focus is on understanding the dynamics and processes involving marine erosion, sediment deposition, as well as the impact of tides and waves.

nodes.name: Aeolian Geomorphology
nodes.description: This aspect of geomorphology investigates the effects of wind on the Earth's landscape. Sand dunes and loess are examples of landforms that are studied in this subfield.

nodes.name: Volcanic Geomorphology
nodes.description: It is the study of landforms and structures created by volcanic activity. It also analyzes geomorphological changes caused by volcanic erosion and weathering over time.

nodes.name: Tectonic Geomorphology
nodes.description: This refers to the study of the creation and alteration of Earth's surface due to the forces within the Earth such as crustal deformation and earthquakes.

nodes.name: Applied Climatology
nodes.description: The application of climatic data to manage society's problems; deals with the use of climate information to solve problems and make decisions in fields such as agriculture, forestry and water resources.

nodes.name: Paleoclimatology
nodes.description: The study of climate change taken on the scale of the entire history of Earth. It uses evidence from ice sheets, tree rings, sediment, and rocks to determine the past state of the climate.

nodes.name: Atmospheric Dynamics
nodes.description: Study of the forces which influence the functioning of the Earth's atmosphere and the motion of air; key for understanding the weather and climate system.

nodes.name: Climate Modelling
nodes.description: Mathematical representation of climate systems based on physical, biological and chemical principles; used for simulating, predicting climate change and its potential effects.

nodes.name: Bioclimatology
nodes.description: The study of the reciprocal effects of climate on living organisms such as plants, animals and humans.

nodes.name: Microclimatology
nodes.description: Study of local climates such as the climates of small areas or specific features (forests, cities, etc.), usually within a few kilometers or less from the surface.

nodes.name: Climatic Classification
nodes.description: System of categorizing the world's climates on the basis of temperature, precipitation and their seasonality with the purpose of simplifying the complexity of climates.

nodes.name: Surface Water Hydrology
nodes.description: This subdiscipline of hydrology focuses on water that is open to the atmosphere, such as rivers, lakes, and streams. It explores aspects such as water cycle, rainfall, and runoff.

nodes.name: Groundwater Hydrology
nodes.description: This branch deals with the study of water below the earth's surface in the saturated zone. It assesses the distribution and movement of groundwater, including its replenishment rates and interaction with the surface water.

nodes.name: Hydrogeology
