nodes.description: Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death that occurs in multicellular organisms. It is a regulated, orderly process that removes unnecessary or damaged cells.

nodes.name: Cell Differentiation
nodes.description: Cell Differentiation is the process by which a less specialized cell becomes a more specialized cell type. It is part of development in multicellular organisms.

nodes.name: Stem Cells and Regenerative Medicine
nodes.description: Stem Cells and Regenerative Medicine involves undifferentiated cells with the ability to differentiate into specialized cell types and renew themselves, and their use in medicine to replace damaged tissues.

nodes.name: Cancer and cell division
nodes.description: This subconcept focuses on how uncontrolled cell growth and division leads to cancer. It often includes a study of oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes, as well as environmental factors.

nodes.name: Intracellular Signaling
nodes.description: Intracellular signaling refers to the process by which cells communicate with each other within their boundaries. It involves signaling molecules (ligands) such as hormones, neurotransmitters or cytokines, to trigger a response within the same cell.

nodes.name: Intercellular Signaling
nodes.description: Intercellular signaling refers to the method by which signals are communicated between cells. It involves the transmission of signals and substances between neighboring or distant cells.

nodes.name: Receptor Activation
nodes.description: Receptor activation is the binding of a ligand (signaling molecule) to a receptor on the cell surface or within the cell, resulting in a change in the receptor's activity.

nodes.name: Signal Transduction
nodes.description: Signal transduction refers to the process by which a cell converts one kind of signal or stimulus into another. It involves multiple stages by emitting signals from proteins or other substances inside the cell.

nodes.name: Cellular Response
nodes.description: Cellular response is the specific reaction of a cell to a signaling event, which may result in changes in the cell's behavior or gene expression.

nodes.name: Endocrine Signaling
nodes.description: Endocrine signaling involves the transmission of signals from a cell through the bloodstream to target cells distant from the signaling cell, often involving hormones.

nodes.name: Paracrine Signalling
nodes.description: Paracrine signalling refers to communication between neighboring cells, where a signal produced by one cell diffuses a short distance to act upon a neighboring cell.

nodes.name: Autocrine Signaling
nodes.description: Autocrine signaling is a type of cell communication where a cell releases a molecule that binds to receptors on its own surface, usually leading to changes in cell function or proliferation.

nodes.name: Cell Structure
nodes.description: This involves studying different parts of the cell and their functions.

nodes.name: Cell Metabolism
nodes.description: It involves understanding the series of chemical reactions that take place within a cell.

nodes.name: Genetics
nodes.description: Studying the heredity and variation in living organisms.

nodes.name: Protein Synthesis
nodes.description: This involves comprehending the process cells use to produce protein.

nodes.name: Molecular Signaling
nodes.description: Investigating how cells communicate and coordinate their actions.

nodes.name: Cell Division
nodes.description: Studying how cells divide and multiply.

nodes.name: Cell Transport
nodes.description: Understanding how substances move in and out of the cell.

nodes.name: Cell Injury and Death
nodes.description: This subconcept involves the study of causes and mechanisms of cell injury and death, including apoptosis and necrosis.

nodes.name: Inflammation and Repair
nodes.description: This subconcept focuses on how the body responds to cell injury to restore normal tissue function, including the processes of inflammation and tissue repair.

nodes.name: Immunopathology
nodes.description: This subconcept involves the study of disease states associated with overactivity or underactivity of the immune response.

nodes.name: Neoplasia
nodes.description: This subconcept involves the study of abnormal tissue growth, known as neoplasms or tumors, including their causes, development, and effects.

nodes.name: Genetic and Pediatric Diseases
nodes.description: This subconcept focuses on diseases that are genetically inherited or predominantly affect pediatric populations.

nodes.name: Environmental and Nutritional Diseases
nodes.description: This subconcept focuses on diseases that result from environmental exposure or nutritional deficiencies or excesses.

nodes.name: General Pathology of Infectious Diseases
nodes.description: This involves studying the cellular response to infectious microbes and the general pathological changes they can cause.

nodes.name: Glycolysis
nodes.description: The first step in cellular respiration that breaks down glucose into two three-carbon molecules, producing ATP and NADH in the process.

nodes.name: Pyruvate Decarboxylation
nodes.description: An intermediate step between glycolysis and the Krebs cycle, where pyruvate from glycolysis is converted into Acetyl CoA.

nodes.name: Krebs Cycle
nodes.description: Also known as the citric acid cycle, it's a series of chemical reactions that generates energy through the oxidation of the acetyl CoA derived from carbohydrates, fats and proteins into ATP and CO2.

nodes.name: Electron Transport Chain (ETC)
nodes.description: The final stage of aerobic respiration which produces the largest amount of ATP. It is a series of proteins in the inner mitochondrial membrane where a high energy electron from NADH and FADH2 is passed along with the release of energy.

nodes.name: Oxidative Phosphorylation
nodes.description: The process of using energy from proton movement to produce ATP in the electron transport chain.

nodes.name: Anaerobic Respiration
nodes.description: A form of respiration using electron acceptors other than oxygen. Despite the fact that there's less ATP produced compared to aerobic respiration, it allows organisms to ensure their survival when oxygen is absent.

nodes.name: Innate Immunity
nodes.description: This refers to the nonspecific component of the immune system that forms the body's first line of defense. It includes physical barriers like skin and mucous membranes, chemicals in the blood, and immune system cells that attack foreign cells in the body.

nodes.name: Adaptive Immunity
nodes.description: This form of immunity creates an immunological memory after an initial response to a specific pathogen, leading to an enhanced response to subsequent encounters with that pathogen.

nodes.name: Cell-Mediated Immunity
nodes.description: This aspect of immunity is mediated by T cells (T lymphocytes) and involves the activation of phagocytes, antigen-specific cytotoxic T-lymphocytes, and the release of various cytokines in response to an antigen.

nodes.name: Humoral Immunity
nodes.description: Also known as antibody-mediated immunity, this is the aspect of immunity that is mediated by macromolecules found in extracellular fluids such as secreted antibodies, complement proteins, and certain antimicrobial peptides.

nodes.name: Immunological Memory
nodes.description: A characteristic of the adaptive immunity where the immune system can quickly and specifically recognize antigens that the body has previously encountered and mount a stronger and faster immune response.

nodes.name: Immune Cell Interactions
nodes.description: This focuses on how immune cells interact with each other and with cells of the body during the immune response. It includes mechanisms of antigen presentation, co-stimulation, and regulation of the immune response.

nodes.name: Cytokine Production and Regulation
nodes.description: Cytokines are small proteins that are crucial in controlling the growth and activity of other immune system cells and blood cells. They are produced by immune cells in response to a stimulus.

nodes.name: Stem Cell Types
nodes.description: This refers to the various types of stem cells like embryonic stem cells, tissue-specific stem cells, mesenchymal stem cells, and induced pluripotent stem cells.

nodes.name: Stem Cell Niches
nodes.description: This studies the 'neighborhood' or environment in the body where stem cells reside which regulates how they function.

nodes.name: Stem Cell Proliferation
nodes.description: It involves the understanding of stem cell division and growth.

nodes.name: Stem Cell Differentiation
nodes.description: This pertains to the process by which a stem cell develops into a more specialized cell type.

nodes.name: Stem Cell Aging
nodes.description: This researches how the functions of stem cells change as they age.

nodes.name: Stem Cell Potency
nodes.description: It refers to the capability of a stem cell to differentiate into different cell types.

nodes.name: Stem Cell Transplantation
nodes.description: This is about the process whereby stem cells are transferred from one individual to another, or from one area of the body to another within the same individual, for the purpose of healing or replacing damaged cells.

nodes.name: Stem Cell Therapies
nodes.description: This examines how stem cells can be used to treat or prevent various diseases, including those for which there are currently no cures.

nodes.name: Embryogenesis
nodes.description: It refers to the process by which the embryo develops from a single-celled zygote to a multi-cellular organism. Embryogenesis is a major subject within developmental biology.

nodes.name: Cell Differentiation
nodes.description: This is the process where a less specialized cell becomes a more specialized cell type. It's relevant to developmental biology because it explains how embryonic cells become specialized cells, such as skin cells or nerve cells.

nodes.name: Flatworm Regeneration
nodes.description: This involves asexual reproduction in certain flatworms, investigating how these organisms can regenerate from a tiny fragment. It provides insights into cell growth and differentiation.

nodes.name: Drosophila melanogaster development
nodes.description: Studies the development of the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, as a model organism. It provides cellular and genetic understanding of the development.

nodes.name: Stem Cell Biology
nodes.description: This focuses on the study of stem cells, which are cells with the unique ability to develop into specialized cell types in the body. It's relevant to developmental biology because it investigates how organisms develop and grow.

nodes.name: Epigenetics in Development
nodes.description: Studying the role that epigenetic modifications play in regulating gene expression during the development of an organism. It helps learn about mechanisms that can turn genes on or off, altering an organism's physical appearance, function, and health.

nodes.name: Morphogenesis
nodes.description: This involves the biological process that causes an organism to develop its shape. It's pertinent in developmental biology as it provides understanding how cell tissue development contribute to the form of an organism.

nodes.name: Organogenesis
nodes.description: The phase of embryonic development that starts at the end of gastrulation and continues until birth. During organogenesis, the three germ layers formed from gastrulation: the ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm form the organs of the organism.

nodes.name: Senescence
nodes.description: The condition or process of deterioration with age. Studies of senescence have direct implications for understanding the biological aging process, life span and longevity.

nodes.name: Gene
nodes.description: A unit of heredity which is transferred from a parent to offspring and is held to determine some characteristic of the offspring.

nodes.name: Allele
nodes.description: One of two or more alternative forms of a gene that arise by mutation and are found at the same place on a chromosome.

nodes.name: Dominant and Recessive Traits
nodes.description: In Mendelian genetics, dominant traits are those that are expressed or show up when a trait is present. Recessive traits are those that are apparent only when two recessive alleles for the same characteristic are inherited.

nodes.name: Genotype and Phenotype
nodes.description: The genotype is the set of genes in our DNA which is responsible for a particular trait. The phenotype is the physical expression, or characteristics, of that trait.

nodes.name: Punnett Square
nodes.description: A square diagram that is used to predict an outcome of a particular cross or breeding experiment.

nodes.name: Mendel's Laws of Inheritance
nodes.description: The laws include the law of segregation (first law), the law of independent assortment (second law), and the law of dominance.

nodes.name: Test Cross
nodes.description: A way to explore the genotype of an organism. This cross, between an organism with a phenotype that dominants the trait in question and an organism with a recessive phenotype, can help to determine whether the first organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the phenotype in question.

nodes.name: Monohybrid and Dihybrid Cross
nodes.description: The monohybrid cross is a breeding experiment between P generation (parental generation) organisms that differ in a single given trait. The dihybrid cross, on the other hand, is a cross between two different lines/genes that differ in two observed traits.

nodes.name: Gene Expression
nodes.description: This is a process through which information from a gene is used in the synthesis of a functional gene product, typically proteins. The study of gene expression allows us to understand when and how genes turn 'on' or 'off'

nodes.name: DNA Replication
nodes.description: This is the process by which a double-stranded DNA molecule is copied to produce two identical DNA molecules. It's fundamental for cell division as it ensures that each new cell has an exact copy of the DNA from the old cell.

nodes.name: Mutation and DNA Repair
nodes.description: This refers to changes that occur in the sequence of the DNA and how these changes are rectified. Understanding mutations and DNA repair mechanisms helps explain how genetic variations and diseases arise.

nodes.name: Genetic Recombination
nodes.description: The process where genetic materials, contained in two parental bodies, combine to generate new combinations of sequences. This concept is crucial in understanding how diversity and evolution occur.

nodes.name: RNA Splicing
nodes.description: This is the process by which the non-coding sequences (introns) are removed from pre-mRNA and the coding sequences (exons) are joined together. It plays a key role in gene expression.

nodes.name: Transposons
nodes.description: Segments of DNA that can move around to different positions within the genome of a single cell. They play a significant role in genome evolution.

nodes.name: Genetic Code
nodes.description: The set of rules used by living cells to translate information encoded within genetic material into proteins. It is fundamental to understanding how sequences in DNA are converted into functional units.

nodes.name: Regulation of Gene Expression
nodes.description: Mechanisms and systems that regulate the expression of genes. Understanding this provides insights into how different cell types develop and how they react to changes in their environment.

nodes.name: Molecular Cloning
nodes.description: A set of experimental methods in molecular biology that are used to assemble recombinant DNA molecules and to direct their replication within host organisms. This is a common method to amplify DNA fragments and create recombinant proteins.

nodes.name: Hardy-Weinberg Principle
nodes.description: This principle states that allele and genotype frequencies in a population remain constant from generation to generation unless they are influenced by factors such as mutation, non-random mating, gene flow, genetic drift, or natural selection.

nodes.name: Mutation
nodes.description: In the context of population genetics, mutation refers to the biological process that leads to changes in the DNA sequence, which introduces new genetic variation in a population.

nodes.name: Genetic Drift
nodes.description: Genetic drift is a mechanism of evolution that refers to random changes in allele frequencies, especially in smaller populations and can result in loss of genetic diversity.

nodes.name: Gene Flow
nodes.description: In population genetics, gene flow refers to the transfer of genetic material from one population to another. This can lessen the genetic diversity among populations, creating a more homogeneously mixed gene pool.

nodes.name: Natural Selection
nodes.description: Natural selection is a mechanism of evolution where individuals with traits that are beneficial for survival and reproduction in their environment have greater chances of passing their genes to the next generation. It has a huge impact on the allele frequency within a population.

nodes.name: Non-random Mating
nodes.description: Non-random mating occurs when the probability that two individuals in a population will mate is not the same for all possible pairs of individuals. This can be due to physical proximity, phenotypic preference, etc. Non-random mating does not change allele frequencies directly, but it alters the expected genotype frequencies.

nodes.name: Genetic Variation
nodes.description: This refers to the diversity in gene frequencies. Genetic variation is essential for natural selection because it allows evolution to proceed by providing the genetic raw materials for adaptation.

nodes.name: Population Structure
nodes.description: Population structure in population genetics refers to the organization of genetic diversity within and between populations. It can be influenced by various factors such as geographical barriers, social structure, or any form of physical boundary which can limit gene flow and cause genetic differentiation.

nodes.name: Fitness and Adaptation
nodes.description: In population genetics, fitness refers to the reproductive success of an individual. Adaptation refers to the process by which populations become better suited to their environment due to natural selection acting upon genetic variation.

nodes.name: Functional Genomics
nodes.description: This is the study of how genes work and interact with each other to produce various traits. It aims to understand the role of genes in the cell or organism using a holistic view.

nodes.name: Structural Genomics
nodes.description: This field focuses on the physical nature of genomes; mainly the structure, organization, and mapping of genes.

nodes.name: Comparative Genomics
nodes.description: This involves the comparison of genomes from different species to understand similarities and differences in genetic content and function. It offers insights into evolutionary processes.

nodes.name: Epigenomics
nodes.description: This is the systematic analysis of patterns of gene expression modifications occurring without changes in DNA sequence, known as epigenetic modifications. It focuses on the structure and function of the genomic landscape.

nodes.name: Cancer Genomics
nodes.description: This is the study of the genetic mutations associated with cancer. The results can lead to improved diagnosis, treatment, and prevention strategies.

nodes.name: Microbial Genomics
nodes.description: This is the study of the genomics of microorganisms such as bacteria, archaea, viruses, fungi, prions, protozoa, and algae.

nodes.name: Pharmacogenomics
nodes.description: The study of how genes affect a person's response to drugs. This is a relatively new field which combines pharmacology (the science of drugs) and genomics (the study of genes and their functions).

nodes.name: Embryonic development
nodes.description: Investigates the process by which the embryo forms and develops, including the roles of specific genes and signalling pathways.

nodes.name: Specification
nodes.description: Study of how cells become determined to specific cell fate or lineages, including the timing and molecular signals involved.

nodes.name: Morphogenesis
nodes.description: The biological process that leads to the formation of the specific shape of an organism, understanding how genetic instructions guide physical development.

nodes.name: Segmentation
nodes.description: Concerns with understanding the division of the body plan of an organism into series of repetitive segments and the role of genes in this process.

nodes.name: Gastraulation
nodes.description: Studies the stage of embryonic development during which primary germ layers form, emphasizing the genetic mechanisms behind.

nodes.name: Organogenesis
nodes.description: Covers the phase of embryonic development that results in organ formation, with a focus on understanding how genetic factors play a role in this process.

nodes.name: Growth and differentiation
nodes.description: Examines how cells differentiate into specific types and how they grow, highlighting the role of genetic instructions on these key developmental processes.

nodes.name: Germ cell development
nodes.description: Investigates the process by which germ cells—cells that give rise to gametes—are formed and developed, including the genetic basis of this process.

nodes.name: Quantitative trait locus (QTL) mapping
nodes.description: A statistical method that links two types of information, phenotypic data (trait measurements) and genotypic data (usually molecular markers), in an attempt to explain the genetic basis of variation in complex traits.

nodes.name: Genetic correlation
nodes.description: A measure of the degree to which the genetic effects on one trait co-vary with the genetic effects on another trait.

nodes.name: Heritability
nodes.description: The proportion of total variation in a trait which is due to genetic factors.

nodes.name: Genetic variance
nodes.description: The component of phenotypic variance that is due to genetic differences among individuals within a population.

nodes.name: Genomic Selection
nodes.description: A type of marker-assisted selection in which effects of markers covering the whole genome are used to predict breeding values and select individuals.

nodes.name: Breeding Value
nodes.description: A predicted genetic value of an individual as a parent, taking into account both its own performance and that of its relatives.

nodes.name: Multivariate analysis in Genetics
nodes.description: A set of statistical techniques used to analyze data that corresponds to more than one trait.

nodes.name: DNA Methylation
nodes.description: DNA Methylation is a biological process by which methyl groups are added to the DNA molecule. It is a crucial part of normal organism development and can suppress the expression of genes.

nodes.name: Histone Modification
nodes.description: Histone Modification refers to the process by which the DNA wrapped around histones is changed in order to control gene expression. These modifications can result in genes being turned on or off.

nodes.name: Non-coding RNA molecules
nodes.description: Non-coding RNA molecules play a crucial role in epigenetic processes. They can guide certain modifications to specific locations in the genome and have an impact on gene expression.

nodes.name: Genomic Imprinting
nodes.description: Genomic Imprinting is an important aspect of epigenetics where certain genes function in a parent-of-origin-specific manner, meaning that the gene's effect differs depending on whether it is of maternal or paternal origin.

nodes.name: Chromatin Remodeling
nodes.description: Chromatin Remodeling involves the reshaping of chromatin from a condensed state to a more open state, allowing access to the DNA for transcription.

nodes.name: Epigenetic clock
nodes.description: An Epigenetic Clock is a type of an aging clock based on epigenetic markers, primarily DNA methylation levels. It is a useful tool for understanding biological aging and age-related diseases.

nodes.name: X-chromosome inactivation
nodes.description: X-chromosome inactivation is a process that occurs in female mammals in which one of the two copies of the X chromosome present in each cell is inactivated to dose compensate for males having only one X-chromosome.

nodes.name: Energy Flow
nodes.description: The transfer and transformation of energy in an ecosystem. It is a process through which the energy enters, changes its form, and exits an ecosystem.

nodes.name: Nutrient Cycling
nodes.description: The recycling of nutrients in an ecosystem. Biological elements or nutrients are transformed and reused in different forms by organisms.

nodes.name: Food Chains and Webs
nodes.description: Representations of the predator-prey relationships between species within an ecosystem or habitat.

nodes.name: Population Dynamics
nodes.description: The study of how population sizes of species in an ecosystem change over time and space.

nodes.name: Community Structure
nodes.description: The organization and functioning of organisms within an ecosystem, influenced by the interactions between species.

nodes.name: Biotic Interactions
nodes.description: The interactions among living organisms, like predation, competition, and mutualism, that affect the functioning and structure of ecosystems.

nodes.name: Decomposition
nodes.description: The process by which organic substances are broken down into a much simpler form of matter.

nodes.name: Ecosystem Stability
nodes.description: The resilience or susceptibility of an ecosystem to disturbances, as well its capability to recover.

nodes.name: Population Size
nodes.description: The total number of individuals of a species living in a particular habitat or ecosystem at a particular time. It gives a quantitative measurement of the size of a population.

nodes.name: Population Density
nodes.description: The measurement of the number of an individual species per unit area or unit volume of habitat. It allows us to understand how the population is spatially distributed.

nodes.name: Population Distribution
nodes.description: It explores the spatial distribution of species in a habitat or ecosystem. It can be uniform, clumped or random depending on species interactions and environmental factors.

nodes.name: Population Growth
nodes.description: This concept investigates how the size of a population changes over a period of time, generally due to factors such as reproduction, survival, and migration.

nodes.name: Life History Strategies
nodes.description: These are the patterns of survival and reproduction adopted by a population. They help to determine the growth, size, and structure of the population over time.

nodes.name: Genetic Variation
nodes.description: Population ecologists also study genetic variation within a population, as it relates to the population's ability to adapt to changing environments.

nodes.name: Carrying Capacity
nodes.description: This is the maximum number of individuals in a species that an environment can support for the long term. It is determined by limiting factors such as food availability, space and disease.

nodes.name: Interactions with other species
nodes.description: This covers how a population interacts with other species in the ecosystem, such as through competition, predation, symbiosis, parasitism, etc.

nodes.name: Human Impact
nodes.description: This studies how human activities affect population dynamics, through factors such as habitat destruction, pollution, overhunting, and climate change.

nodes.name: Conservation and Management Strategies
nodes.description: This concept explores the measures taken to protect and manage populations, such as creating protected areas, imposing hunting restrictions, and restoring habitats.

nodes.name: Species Interactions
nodes.description: An examination of the interactions between different species within a community, which can include predation, competition, mutualism, and more.

nodes.name: Biodiversity
nodes.description: The study of variety and variability among living organisms and the ecosystems in which they occur. This includes diversity within species, between species, and among ecosystems.

nodes.name: Community Dynamics
nodes.description: Analyzing how community structure changes over time and what drives those changes.

nodes.name: Food Webs
nodes.description: Studying the interconnecting food chains in an ecological community, detailing who eats whom and the consequences for the community.

nodes.name: Ecological Niches
nodes.description: An exploration of how a species fits into its environment, looking at its specific role and position in an ecosystem, both in the context of its habitat and in relation to other species.

nodes.name: Succession
nodes.description: The process of change in the species structure of an ecological community over time.

nodes.name: Disturbance and Resilience
nodes.description: Investigating how ecological communities respond to disturbances, such as fire, flooding, or human activity, and how they recover (or not) over time.

nodes.name: Ecological Networks
nodes.description: The study of the interactions among species within a community, treating them as interconnected networks rather than isolated species.

nodes.name: Community Structure
nodes.description: Exploring the physical structure of a community, including species distribution patterns, organization of biodiversity, and the effects of environmental factors on these patterns.

nodes.name: Trophic Levels
nodes.description: Investigates the different levels of the food chain in a community and how energy moves through these levels.

nodes.name: Optimal Foraging Theory
nodes.description: This theory predicts that, given the constraint of time and energy, an animal's behavior will maximize the possible benefits of food intake.

nodes.name: Habitat Selection
nodes.description: This concept refers to the process by which organisms choose the environment in which they will live. It covers considerations regarding predation risks, available food sources, and competition with other species.

nodes.name: Altruism in Animals
nodes.description: This refers to behaviors that reduce an individual's fitness while increasing the fitness of other individuals in the population. It is a key concept because it appears to contradict the idea of 'survival of the fittest'.

nodes.name: Social Systems and Structures
nodes.description: This subconcept covers how organisms organize in relation to each other within populations and communities, highlighting cooperation, competition, and social hierarchies.

nodes.name: Mate Choice and Sexual Selection
nodes.description: This involves the mechanisms, reasons, and implications of mate selection, addressing how preferences, competition, and environmental factors determine reproductive success.

nodes.name: Predator-Prey Interactions
nodes.description: This looks at how predators and prey interact, including the strategies used by both parties for hunting and evading, respectively.

nodes.name: Evolutionary Stable Strategies
nodes.description: These are strategies that, once adopted by a population in a given environment, cannot be invaded by any alternative strategy that is initially rare.

nodes.name: Biodiversity
nodes.description: The study of the vast variety of life forms in an ecosystem, including their genetic variations, and the roles these species play in their environment.

nodes.name: Species Extinction
nodes.description: The study of processes and factors leading to the end of an organism or of a group of organisms. Particularly focused on preventing such occurrences.

nodes.name: Population Ecology
nodes.description: The investigation of how individual organism's behaviors, including birth, death, growth, and migration, affect population structures and dynamics.

nodes.name: Habitat Conservation
nodes.description: Focus on conserving, restoring and enhancing the environments where species live. This usually involves the management of the physical and biological aspects.

nodes.name: Conservation Genetics
nodes.description: Focus on understanding the role and requirement of genetic variation for population survival. This field uses genetic methods to answer questions in conservation biology.

nodes.name: Ecological Restoration
nodes.description: The practice of renewing and restoring degraded, damaged, or destroyed ecosystems and habitats in the environment by active human intervention and action.

nodes.name: Invasive Species Management
nodes.description: Study involving prevention, early detection, and the management and control of species introduced outside their natural past or present distribution.

nodes.name: Sustainable Resource Use
nodes.description: The study of practices that reduce our use of non-renewable resources, or which enhance the renewal, recycling and reuse of resources.

nodes.name: Climate Change Adaptation
nodes.description: The study of how changes in our climate impact ecosystems and the species living within them, especially with regard to variations in temperature and precipitation.

nodes.name: Landscape Ecology
nodes.description: Involves studying and improving the relationship between spatial patterns and ecological processes on a multitude of scales and organizational levels.

nodes.name: Habitat Fragmentation
nodes.description: This explores how large continuous areas of habitat are transformed into a number of smaller patches of smaller total area, isolated from each other by a matrix of habitats unlike the original.

nodes.name: Landscape Heterogeneity
nodes.description: This focuses on the patterns of spatial variation in landscapes at a range of scales. It plays a significant role in biodiversity and ecological processes.

nodes.name: Landscape Connectivity
nodes.description: This evaluates the degree to which the landscape facilitates or impedes movement between resource patches.

nodes.name: Scale and Scaling
nodes.description: This subconcept tackles the issues related to the scale at which ecological processes occur and how they can be studied on different scales.

nodes.name: Landscape Pattern Analysis
nodes.description: This involves studying and quantifying spatial patterns in landscapes.

nodes.id: 913 - Land Use and Land Cover Change
nodes.name: Land Use and Land Cover Change
nodes.description: Investigates how human activities affect the composition, structure and function of landscapes.

nodes.name: Landscape Metrics
nodes.description: This focuses on the methods to quantitatively describe and analyze landscape structures and patterns.

nodes.name: Landscape Planning
nodes.description: This applies the principles of landscape ecology in land-use planning and environmental management.

nodes.name: Cultural Landscapes
nodes.description: This considers the complex interactions between human societies and the landscapes they inhabit and modify.

nodes.name: Population Genetics
nodes.description: The study of genetic variation within populations, and involves the examination and modelling of changes in the frequencies of genes and alleles in populations over space and time.

nodes.name: Phylogeography
nodes.description: The study of the historical processes that may be responsible for the contemporary geographic distributions of individuals. This is accomplished by considering the geographic distribution of individuals in light of the patterns associated with a gene genealogy.

nodes.name: Conservation Genetics
nodes.description: A subfield of genetics that aims to understand the genetic diversity and loss of diversity within a species, so as to inform conservation efforts.

nodes.name: Quantitative Genetics
nodes.description: The study of complex characters and their underlying genes that contribute to the diversity of such characters observed in the population.

nodes.name: Ecological Genomics
nodes.description: The study of the genetic mechanisms that regulate the interactions between organisms and their environment.

nodes.name: Metapopulation Dynamics
nodes.description: A major focus in spatial ecology, looking at how populations are interconnected and how their demographics fluctuate in time and space.

nodes.name: Molecular Adaptation
nodes.description: Investigation of how organisms adapt to their environments at a molecular level, focusing on adaptation in DNA sequences and the genetic basis of adaptation.

nodes.name: Adaptive Evolution
nodes.description: The long-term process through which species evolve traits that allow them to thrive in their respective environments.

nodes.name: Natural Selection
nodes.description: The process that determines which traits are advantageous for survival and reproduction, and thus are more likely to be passed on to future generations.

nodes.name: Coevolution
nodes.description: The process through which two or more species reciprocally affect each other's evolution.

nodes.name: Life History Evolution
nodes.description: This explores the biological conditions and environmental influences that result in the diverse range of animal and plant life patterns.

nodes.name: Phylogenetics
nodes.description: A branch of life science dealing with the analysis of evolutionary relationships among species or among groups of species.

nodes.name: Population Genetics
nodes.description: The study of genetic variation within populations and involves the examination and modelling of changes in the frequencies of genes and alleles in populations over space and time.

nodes.name: Ecological Speciation
nodes.description: The process where ecologically based divergent selection between different environments leads to the creation of reproductive isolation and thus, new species.

nodes.name: Plant Physiological Ecology
nodes.description: Focuses on the physiology of plant responses and adaptations to their environment. It includes concepts like photosynthesis, respiration, water relations, light interception, and nutrient uptake.

nodes.name: Animal Physiological Ecology
nodes.description: Investigates the physiological responses of animals to changes in their environment, including body temperature regulation, food and water intake, metabolism, and energy expenditure.

nodes.name: Microbial Physiological Ecology
nodes.description: Studies the physiological aspects and activities of microorganisms such as bacteria, archaea and fungi in their various environmental niches.

nodes.name: Environmental Stress Physiology
nodes.description: Explains how plants, animals, and microbes adapt their physiological processes to survive in harsh environmental conditions or large fluctuations.

nodes.name: Ecophysiological Modeling
nodes.description: Entails the use of mathematical models to depict the relationship between organisms' physiological traits and their environment, predicting how they may respond to environmental changes.

nodes.name: Functional Morphology
nodes.description: Concerns with the relationship between the physical attributes of organisms and their physiological functions, emphasizing how morphology influences physiological processes in various ecological contexts.

nodes.name: Fossil Analysis
nodes.description: This involves studying fossils to understand the types and variety of species that existed in past ecosystems, how they interacted and their individual roles in the ecosystem.

nodes.name: Paleoclimatology
nodes.description: It is the study of past climates, based on a direct comparison with the climate of today. This helps understand how climate evolves and provides a base line for comparative studies on ecosystem changes.

nodes.name: Paleogeography
nodes.description: A paleogeography study involves the historical reconstruction of the Earth's landforms and bodies of water, as well as their interconnecting pathways. This helps paleoecologists understand geographic features of ancient ecosystems.

nodes.name: Biostratigraphy
nodes.description: Biostratigraphy is the study of the vertical distribution of fossils in the sedimentary record. It can reveal information about species' evolution and extinction events.

nodes.name: Paleobotany
nodes.description: Paleobotany is the study of fossilized plants. This is a key aspect of paleoecology because plants are primary producers in an ecosystem and can provide insights into ecosystem functions and climate conditions.

nodes.name: Statistic Paleontology
nodes.description: This subconcept refers to the mathematical analysis and modeling of paleontological data. It helps identify patterns and interrelationships among various factors in ancient ecosystems.

nodes.name: Geochronology
nodes.description: Geochronology is the science of determining the age of rocks, fossils, and sediments. It provides a timeline and chronological context to paleoecological studies.

nodes.name: Ichnology
nodes.description: Ichnology is the study of traces caused by organism activity (tracks, trails, burrows etc.), offering insights into behavior and interaction of species in past ecosystems.

nodes.name: Taphonomy
nodes.description: Taphonomy is the study of how organisms decay and become fossilized. This provides important context that helps interpret the paleoecological data extracted from fossils.

nodes.name: Paleoanthropology
nodes.description: Although primarily a subfield of anthropology, it interacts significantly with paleoecology. It involves studying human evolution and its environmental context, examining human adaptation to changing ecosystems.

nodes.name: Biological Adaptation
nodes.description: The process by which organisms adjust to new environments or to changes in their current environment.

nodes.name: Evolutionary Adaptation
nodes.description: The increase in frequency of a gene variant (allele) in a population due to differential reproduction of individuals with different combinations of genes.

nodes.name: Physiological Adaptation
nodes.description: A short-term physiological response to stress, often associated with homeostasis.

nodes.name: Anatomical Adaptation
nodes.description: Physical changes in the body structure of an organism.

nodes.name: Behavioral Adaptation
nodes.description: Altered behavior that helps an organism to survive or reproduce.

nodes.name: Adaptive Radiation
nodes.description: The diversification of a group of organisms into forms filling different ecological niches.

nodes.name: Mimicry
nodes.description: A form of adaptation where a species develops similarities to another species to gain advantage.

nodes.name: Camouflage
nodes.description: An adaptation that allows organisms to blend in with certain aspects of their environment.

nodes.name: Variation
nodes.description: The occurrence of an organism in more than one distinct color, form, etc. within a species. It's differences in DNA among individuals, especially differences which occur naturally as opposed to those introduced by scientists in a lab.

nodes.name: Inheritance
nodes.description: The passing of traits from parents to their offspring, either through asexual reproduction or sexual reproduction. This is the process by which an offspring cell or organism acquires or becomes predisposed to the characteristics of its parent cell or organism.

nodes.name: High rate of population growth
nodes.description: This suggests that, when allowed, species population can increase rapidly. However, because of limited resources (like food and space), not all individuals survive and reproduce. This leads to the struggle for existence.

nodes.name: Differential Survival and Reproduction
nodes.description: Organisms that are better adapted to their environment will survive and reproduce more effectively than less adapted organisms. This process of 'survival of the fittest' helps contribute to the evolution of species.

nodes.name: Adaptation
nodes.description: Organisms adapt to their environment, and those adaptations are passed on to their offspring. These adaptations may be physical or behavioral, but all are aimed at promoting survival and reproductive success.

nodes.name: Speciation
nodes.description: The formation of new and distinct species in the course of evolution. It occurs when populations of a species become isolated and evolve different traits due to natural selection or genetic drift.

nodes.name: Sympatric Speciation
nodes.description: A type of speciation where new species evolve from a single ancestral species while inhabiting the same geographic region.

nodes.name: Allopatric Speciation
nodes.description: A type of speciation that occurs when biological populations of the same species become vicariant, or isolated from each other to an extent that prevents or interferes with genetic interchange.

nodes.name: Peripatric Speciation
nodes.description: A mode of speciation that occurs when small groups of individuals break off from the larger group to form a new species.

nodes.name: Parapatric Speciation
nodes.description: Speciation pattern in which populations evolve into separate species while in contact along a common border.

nodes.name: Punctuated Equilibrium
nodes.description: In evolutionary biology, it's a theory that proposes that once species appear in the fossil record they will become stable, showing little net evolutionary change for most of their geological history.

nodes.name: Phyletic Gradualism
nodes.description: A model of evolution which theorizes that most speciation is slow, uniform and gradual.

nodes.name: Adaptive Radiation
nodes.description: The diversification of a group of organisms into forms filling different ecological niches.

nodes.name: Bottleneck Effect
nodes.description: The bottleneck effect is a type of genetic drift which describes the sharp reduction in the size of a population due to environmental events like earthquakes, floods etc., which reduces the diversity of the gene pool.

nodes.name: Founder Effect
nodes.description: The founder effect is a type of genetic drift where a new population is established by a very small number of individuals, resulting in a small genetic diversity in the new population.

nodes.name: Neutral Theory of Molecular Evolution
nodes.description: This theory asserts that most evolutionary change at the molecular level is caused by genetic drift of mutant alleles that are neutral rather than by natural selection.

nodes.name: Fixation
nodes.description: In genetics, fixation is the state where every individual in a population has the same allele at a particular locus, usually occurring as a result of genetic drift.

nodes.name: Variation
nodes.description: This refers to the level of heterogeneity within a population's genetic makeup. It forms the basis of genetic drift as the mechanism acts on the gene frequency.

nodes.name: Population Genetics
nodes.description: This is the study of genetic variation within populations, and involves the examination and modelling of changes in the frequencies of genes and alleles in a population over time.

nodes.name: Mutualistic Co-evolution
nodes.description: This subconcept of co-evolution refers to the process where two or more species reciprocally affect each other's evolution for their mutual benefit. Examples include the relationship between flowers and their pollinators.

nodes.name: Parasitic Co-evolution
nodes.description: Parasitic co-evolution refers to the situation where the parasite and the host undergo evolutionary changes in response to each other, often resulting in an arms race of adaptations and counter adaptations.

nodes.name: Competitive Co-evolution
nodes.description: Competitive co-evolution happens when different species, or individuals within a species, compete for limited resources and thus influence each other's evolution. This drives divergent evolution and specialization.

nodes.name: Predator-Prey Co-evolution
nodes.description: One of the most common forms of co-evolution, predator-prey co-evolution refers to the process where predators and their prey continually adapt and evolve in response to each other.

nodes.name: Coevolutionary Arms Race
nodes.description: This refers to a subconcept of co-evolution characterized by escalating adaptations and counter-adaptations between interacting species, usually a predator and its prey or a parasite and its host.

nodes.name: Symbiotic Co-evolution
nodes.description: Symbiotic co-evolution is a process where two species that live in close physical contact, such as mutualism, commensalism or parasitism, affect each other's evolution.

nodes.name: Sexual Co-evolution
nodes.description: This subconcept occurs when the evolutionary changes in one sex create selection pressures that influence the evolution of the other sex, like in the case of sexually dimorphic traits or mating strategies.

nodes.name: Cospeciation
nodes.description: Cospeciation is a form of co-evolution where two or more lineages (or species) reciprocally affect each other's evolution and speciation processes.

nodes.name: Escalation
nodes.description: This subconcept of co-evolution involves the process of progressive increase in intensity or magnitude, usually used in the context of an ongoing evolutionary arms race.

nodes.name: Diffuse Coevolution
nodes.description: Diffuse coevolution is a subconcept where a group of species reciprocally influence each other's evolution, as opposed to pairwise coevolution.

nodes.name: Phenotypic Diversity
nodes.description: This subconcept discusses the role of evolutionary developmental biology in the generation of phenotypic diversity in the ecological context.

nodes.name: Gene Functional Change
nodes.description: Biodiversity seems to be largely due to changes in the function of genes, a subconcept that explores these evolutionary gene functional changes.

nodes.name: Developmental Vitaminosis and Antivitaminosis
nodes.description: A subconcept examining the effects of vitamin fluctuation on the growth and development of organisms as well as their evolutionary significance.

nodes.name: Evolution of Developmental Processes
nodes.description: This topic explores how developmental processes have evolved across different species and the forces that drive this change.

nodes.name: Gene Regulation and Evolution
nodes.description: The study of how gene regulation evolves and influences developmental processes and outcomes.

nodes.id: 989 - Patterning and Shaping of the Body Plan
nodes.name: Patterning and Shaping of the Body Plan
nodes.description: This subconcept addresses how an organism's physical form or body plan is established and modified through evolutionary time.

nodes.name: Evolution of Reproduction and Aging
nodes.description: Examining how lifespan and reproductive strategies influence evolution, and how these traits might have evolved.

nodes.name: Eco-Evolutionary Dynamics
nodes.description: This topic studies interactions between ecological and evolutionary processes, and how they influence development.

nodes.name: Sequence Alignment
nodes.description: A method of arranging sequences of DNA, RNA, or protein to identify regions of similarity. It can be used as evidence of functional, structural or evolutionary relationships among genes or protein sequences.

nodes.name: Phylogenetics
nodes.description: The study of evolutionary relationships among groups of organisms. Phylogenetic trees are used to depict the evolutionary history and genetic relationships among species.

nodes.name: Population Genetics
nodes.description: The study of genetic variation within populations and involves the examination and modelling of changes in the frequencies of genes and alleles in populations over space and time.

nodes.name: Molecular Clock
nodes.description: A technique in molecular evolution that uses fossil constraints and rates of molecular change to deduce the time in geologic history when two species or other taxa diverged.

nodes.name: Comparative Genomics
nodes.description: The field of biology which is concerned with the study of the genomes of different species or strains. This is used to understand gene function and evolution.

nodes.name: Genetic Drift
nodes.description: A mechanism of evolution in which allele frequencies of a population change over generations due to chance (sampling error). It can result in the random loss or fixation of alleles.

nodes.name: Natural Selection
nodes.description: A key mechanism of evolution, it is the differential survival and reproduction of individuals due to differences in phenotype. It is a key driver of adaptive evolution.

nodes.name: Molecular Phylogenetics
nodes.description: This discipline uses techniques and information about molecules to infer evolutionary relationships among species or groups of species.

nodes.name: Phylogenetic Trees
nodes.description: These are diagrams that depict the lineage of species and the relationships between them. The branching patterns represent the inferred evolutionary relationships.

nodes.name: Evolutionary Biology
nodes.description: A broader concept that studies all aspects of organismal evolution, including the ones studied in phylogenetics.

nodes.name: Cladistics
nodes.description: An approach in Phylogenetics that categorizes organisms based on the principle of the last common ancestor. It tries to construct a tree-like 'cladogram' that represents the complete evolutionary course.

nodes.name: Computational Phylogenetics
nodes.description: This discipline uses computational algorithms, methods, and programs to analyze and interpret phylogenetic relationships.

nodes.name: Species Concept
nodes.description: A set of criteria used to identify and distinguish species, using phylogenetic considerations.

nodes.name: Phylogeography
nodes.description: Studying the geological processes and historical events that may have influenced the current distribution of lineages.
